source_data: Data used: client number, district, date of birth, school, absenteeism report, id and availability of compulsory school officer, open data on schools and compulsory school officers.
methods_and_models: Mixed Integer Linear Programming.
human_intervention: No automated decision-making will take place. The model will only be used to advise compulsory education officers which reports they can take up.
risks: No risk. The model outcomes are so-called opinions, which are based on assumptions the model is fed with. It is important to understand the assumptions well so that the model outcomes can be interpreted properly. The model is decision-supportive and not decision-taking. No processing of personal data takes place, except for client number, district information and date of birth.
impact: With smart deployment and implementation, the impact leads to a) shorter turnaround times, b) lower work stocks , c) rationalisation of priorities to pick up absenteeism reports, d) more efficient deployment of FTEs.
decision_making_process: Allocation Compulsory Education Officers.
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague
dpia_description: A privacy check was done and a DPIA was not necessary.
objection_procedure: No, the algorithm is for internal use only.
description: The algorithm generates (using a set of rules and Mixed Integer Linear Programming) a work list for truancy officers containing the absence reports that can be picked up. The model calculates which absence report can be assigned to which truancy officer. The calculated value is 'only' an advice for the truancy officer. The official may have motives to pick up other reports.
monitoring: The only risk could lie in automating decision-making. This is not happening at the moment, nor is it in the plan to automate decision-making.
performance_standard: Level of workload, average processing time for absenteeism, number of FTEs.

name: Automated facial comparison in the RNI registration process
description_short: Algorithm that can help registrants avoid "look-alike fraud". Sourced from the National Authority for Identity Data (RvIG)
goal: The algorithm was developed to compare the face of the person in front of the counter with the image in his identity document and to indicate with what certainty it can be stated that the person shown in the image of the scanned identity document is the same person (or not). This algorithm supports the RNI employee at the counter so that he can determine with some certainty whether the person at the counter is also the person whose identity document has been scanned.
proportionality: The deployment of this algorithm helps the RNI employee establish the identity of the citizen at the counter.
lawful_basis: Legal obligation to establish proper identity: BRP Act Art. 2.67 4th paragraph, BRP Decree Art.35 Admissibility of biometrics: UAVG Art. 29, in the present situation authentication is necessary.
methods_and_models: Deep learning. Advanced face recognition APIs: C++, Java, Microsoft .NET, BioAPI 2.0 Verification Engine (C API). Documented examples for key use cases and specific implementations. Tools for biometric evaluations, including generation of 'identification match' views and 'similarity matrix' data.
human_intervention: Yes. Ultimately, the RNI officer decides whether to use the facial scan and what to do with the result of the facial scan in the process
risks: A risk is a probability of the occurrence of a negative consequence for the rights and freedoms of data subjects as a result of the processing of personal data. However, because in the situation described no storage is required (because facial image is only recorded in the system during the process of identity determination and visible to the employees of the RNI counter), the risk of leakage or manipulation of the facial image is small.
impact: If the application using the algorithm indicates that the person whose identity document has been scanned is not the person standing at the counter, the RNI employee will have to decide for himself whether this is justified or not. The RNI employee at the counter is ultimately the one with final responsibility. If he finds the rejection by the algorithm justified, the application for registration in the BRP will be rejected by the citizen. This rejection may include an indication of whether fraud is suspected.
decision_making_process: Basic registration
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague
description: When registering a citizen in the RNI, a scanning solution is used. This scanning solution consists of an ID scanner, an A4 scanner, a scan server, a small monitor and, since February 2021, also a face scanner. This scanning solution supports the RNI employee in the registration process and, since the use of the face scanner, also in establishing identity. The data from the scanned identity document is displayed on the small monitor and if there are no details, the scanned data passes from the scanning solution to the RNI application. The data used to establish identity is not passed to the RNI application, but the result is displayed on the small monitor. The data from the scanned identity document is used for registration in RNI after approval by the RNI employee. Of the face scan performed, it is only passed on to RNI in a log line that it was performed and what the result was. This result may be: 'The faces are the same' or 'The faces are not the same'.
application_url:
https://www.oribi.nl/
ORIBI-ID solutions - Zekerheid geeft vertrouwen
performance_standard: NIST tests are used at the RvIG to evaluate performance.

name: Population forecast model
description_short: The population forecast provides Insight into the composition, distribution and future size of the population.
category: Demography, Housing, Education, Strategy, Care and Welfare, Urban Development, Economy
goal: Understanding the (possible) future development of The Hague's population by age.
proportionality: GBPRO is a model created by and for Dutch municipalities. There are no comparable alternatives available where you can best estimate the situation in terms of mortality, birth and migration at local (municipality) level.
lawful_basis: Input is necessary for municipal policy.
source_data: Aggregate data of at least 5 years for: Basic population by age and sex Births by maternal age Mortality by age and sex Departure Domestic by age and sex Departure Abroad by age and sex Settlement Domestic by age and sex Settlement Abroad by age and sex The most up-to-date housing construction programming
methods_and_models: Based on the assumption of the (corrected) probabilities, the forecast for the first year by age and sex is prepared by first determining the correction for domestic departure, after which the total departures domestic and foreign are determined. To then determine the number of births, first settlement, departure, both domestic and foreign, and mortality are calculated, after which the total number of births can be calculated. Once the number of births is calculated, these are zeroed out and divided by sex. The process then determines departures again, inflows and deaths. The final step is the initial population by age and sex plus settlement by age and sex minus departure by age and sex minus mortality by age and sex. This last cycle yields the final population of the first forecast year. This population is the starting population of the second forecast year. In this way, the forecast is calculated the set number of years ahead. Using the correction matrix, it is possible to recalculate the forecast with a changed assumption.
human_intervention: Yes, specifying parameters such as future fertility, mortality probabilities, immigration and emigration, housing stock. The results of the model are input for processing by various policy fields, through human intervention. The algorithm is run at the request of the Board of B&W and is advisory only. B&W can decide to stop forecasting. Policy processes are not stopped.
risks: Results of the model are always analysed by specialists.
impact: The model has no direct impact on citizens' daily lives.
decision_making_process: The outcomes are input for municipal policymakers such as e.g. in the fields of spatial planning, urban development, social development, labour market, public housing, economy, health and welfare and education.
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague
dpia_description: No DPIA required. Did check with privacy officer.
objection_procedure: No personal data so not applicable.
description: The Input The (basic) input of the model consists of the variables/files listed below.  Population: the state population as of 1 January. This population is broken down by 1-year age group and gender. This is the starting population of this forecast.  Births: by year the number of births by mother's age. Mother's age should be given in 1-year groups (15-49 year olds). In connection with determining the sex ratio, it is important to show boys and girls separately.  Mortality: per year the number of deceased persons by 1-year age group and sex. Departure within the country: per year the number of persons leaving the city to a location within the Netherlands by 1-year age group and sex. Departure abroad: per year the number of persons departing from the city to a location outside the Netherlands by 1-year age group and gender.  Settlement in the Netherlands: per year the number of people settling in the city from the Netherlands by 1-year age group and sex.  Settlement abroad: per year the number of persons settling in the city from outside the Netherlands by 1-year age group and sex.  Housing stock and housing construction programme: the housing stock is based on the BAG housing stock as of 1 January. The housing construction programme is based on the new construction (including transformation) and demolition programme of mid-December (DSO/SEPO).  For the analysis and probability calculation of past events, data for at least 4 years of the variables should be entered. For the analysis of The Hague, the state data from the BRP from 1/1/1996 to 1 January of the most recent year available were used, and for the flow data the data from 1996 to the most recent year. These eight files are the basic data from which the city forecast is prepared. From these basic files, total domestic settlement and total domestic departure are calculated for each year. Furthermore, the balance of settlement minus departure is determined for each year. These data are needed to determine average settlement, average departure and settlement balance. These calculated values are used in the forecast to determine total domestic departures and to determine the correction factor for the domestic departure probability.  The probabilities From the base files, probabilities are calculated for each event by age and sex. The probabilities calculated are: an age-specific fertility probability, a mortality probability by age and sex, a domestic and foreign departure probability by age and sex, and a domestic and foreign settlement probability by age and sex. Correction factors When calculating probabilities, it is necessary to apply some corrections. The first correction concerns a correction of the settlement probabilities. The idea behind this is that an ageing population of the Netherlands will also produce a higher proportion of older settlers. The probabilities are corrected for the development per age group in the Dutch population as projected by CBS in 2019. Further corrections are given in the so-called correction matrix. This correction matrix is filled based on the specific Hague municipal situation in order to obtain a forecast that fits the municipality. The matrix consists of the following elements: - the fertility level, or Total fertility rate (Tfr) - the balance of domestic and foreign establishment (Salit and Salut) - the sex ratio (the ratio of boy to girl births).
monitoring: Results of the model are always analysed by specialists.
performance_standard: Annually, the results of the forecast are compared with the realisation.

name: Prediction model Youth Aid
description_short: The Youth Aid prediction model predicts the number of unique young people with Youth Aid without a stay with a six-year prediction horizon. Besides the number of young people, predictions are also made on costs. Predictions are made at district level, for city districts and for all of The Hague.
goal: The algorithm was developed because the municipality of The Hague wants to be better prepared for the future. If the municipality knows how many young people are expected to make use of Youth Care without Residence over the next six years and the costs involved, it can better anticipate this demand and continue to provide the support to all young people who need it in the future.
proportionality: No
lawful_basis: There is no legal basis for the forecasting model, but the municipality is responsible for implementing the Youth Act and the model allows the municipality to better anticipate expected developments and better support citizens.
source_data: Only open data was used, namely the file Kerncijfers Wijken en Buurten CBS and the file 'Young people with youth care and youth care pathways in kind; neighbourhoods' from CBS.
methods_and_models: The model is a regression model. The performance of this model is measured by the measures RMSE, MAE and MAPE. These are measures that variously determine how large the prediction error is.
human_intervention: Yes, there is no automated system. The insights from the prediction model can only be used through human intervention and with the context knowledge and experience of staff involved. If it is decided that the model is no longer usable, this decision will be made by the model owner (portfolio director of Youth Care) and those directly involved will be informed.
risks: The risks of the algorithm were identified in advance and during the construction of the prediction model. Because the prediction model does not make statements about individuals but about the use of facilities in neighbourhoods, there was no risk that the results from the model could violate the privacy of specific individuals. Furthermore, we only worked with neighbourhoods that were sufficiently large (more than 100 inhabitants) and where a sufficient number of people were using Youth Services (more than 70 users). One reason is that this does not allow for disclosure. That is, by combining characteristics, we cannot identify who the potential users of Youth Aid services are. Furthermore, when building the model, we weighed up together with the privacy officer and the ethical officer which variables could and could not be included from a privacy perspective. Here, the AVG was always the starting point. In addition, explainability of the model and the results is a relevant and decisive criterion. The question of what role bias plays in the use of the algorithm is far too general a question, as there are many forms of bias. If it is bias targeting specific population groups, it does not play a role in this model. We are not looking for specific individual people with specific characteristics, but want to estimate the use of Youth Care without Residence in the whole district and for all of The Hague.
impact: The forecasting model makes no statements about (chances of) individual citizens and models have been chosen that are explainable. This means that, as a municipality, we do not use models for which it is difficult to determine how the model arrived at a certain outcome (so-called Black Box models). The Youth Predictive Model in no way replaces the knowledge and skills of our consultants and implementation. The tool is not meant for them, but mainly for policy and making and substantiating policy choices for the longer term. It is precisely through the knowledge of the Youth Predictive Model that we can anticipate in time and continue to better support all individuals.
decision_making_process: The insights from the Youth Forecasting Model support policy and implementation in answering tactical and strategic questions. These are questions and topics that are relevant in the longer term (e.g. 5 to 10 years). The model is not intended to answer operational questions (short-term issues) and does not involve automated decisions.
competent_authority: The Youth Aid prediction model does not use person-level characteristics
objection_procedure: Given the nature of the model, this is not regulated.
description: A regression model is used to estimate the relationship between Youth Aid use and predictors. This involves searching for the characteristics with the smallest prediction error (determined using the measures: RMSE, MAE and MAPE). The characteristics best able to predict Youth Aid use are used for forecasting. Forecasts are made within a prediction interval of 80 per cent.
monitoring: If it is necessary to build/train a new model, the privacy officer will be involved in the choice of features and an entirely new model will also revisit the ethical framework.
performance_standard: The model is updated annually. Forecasts from the old model are compared with forecasts from the new model and compared with realisations.

name: Forecast crowds and ballot paper usage at polling stations
description_short: Based on the turnout in the first 3 hours (according to the Polling StationApp), a forecast is made over the next 10 hours for crowding and ballot paper take-up.
goal: For signalling potential crowding and related ballot consumption. The algorithm scores normal, quiet and busy. This score is visible on the Queue app for the public. In addition, the election control room uses the data to advise the polling station chairman on additional ballot papers needed. It can also be decided by the polling station chairperson to refer people to another polling station.
proportionality: First version was a count of the actual number of visitors in the Polling Station as input for stock control of the number of ballot papers. This did not work as well.
lawful_basis: Electoral Act
source_data: The Polling StationApp records that people voted but not who. The numbers are used for the algorithm. No dependencies
methods_and_models: Hourly averages, historical curves over time and linear regression.
human_intervention: Yes. The algorithm can be stopped in the app at any time and replaced by counts by Polling Station members. As for the process, the Control Room decides to post ballot papers and can also decide not to do so. The crowding indicator in the QueueApp can use data from the algorithm but also data entered by Polling Station members.
risks: No risk because voter decides which polling station to visit. No automated decision-making. Bias does not play a role because the number of voters is counted independently of personal data.
impact: The voter decides whether to use the Queue app and the data generated by the algorithm.
decision_making_process: No direct decision-making, indication of possible crowding and/or low stock of ballot papers. For action, look specifically at stocks and crowding at specific polling stations
competent_authority: The Hague municipality is a data controller. No personal data are involved, only counts.
objection_procedure: No
description: Based on turnout 3 first hours of opening of each polling station (source Polling StationApp), the average per hour per polling station is calculated and then a forecast is made per polling station over the next 10 hours. For crowding, categorisation is made to Normal, Average and Crowded based on historical turnout curves for all polling stations, in the categories Small, Ordinary, Large, Extra Large. For ballot paper consumption, a linear forecast is made based on usage.
monitoring: N/A
performance_standard: Algorithm is simple, error-free, counts and displays.

name: Left luggage detection
description_short: Recognising attached waste next to underground containers
goal: The algorithm was originally developed for detection of forgotten luggage. Works well with fixed cameras (not rotatable or zoomable) and in sufficient light. Does not work well in dynamic environments or in darkness.
proportionality: All 'lighter' means (more surveillance, more information on rules, more containers and dozens more) have been tried and did not yield the desired results. Cameras are now also being used as an additional tool.
lawful_basis: Art. 151c Gemeentewet, jo. APV and Afvalstoffenverordening Den Haag
source_data: Camera footage
methods_and_models: The algorithm rests with the suppliers. Municipality purchases services and has no substantive knowledge of how the algorithm works.
human_intervention: Yes, see description. It can be decided to deactivate the algorithm in the camera system. In addition, the camera system itself can also be deactivated.
risks: A Data Protection Impact Assessment (GEB) and a Data Privacy Impact Assessment (DPIA) were carried out for the project. The only risk is a false positive (it looks like an addition but is not) or a false negative (it was an addition but the algorithm did not recognise it). In both cases, there are no consequences for the individual. In the case of a false positive, the enforcer removes the images after review. In the case of a false negative, nothing happens to the images. Images without recognition are automatically deleted by the system. There is no processing of personal data in the algorithm: the algorithm gives a hit if it detects that a non-moving object remains for a longer period of time. The camera images do show recognisable people in the image but these are only viewed by designated enforcers after a signal from the algorithm.
impact: The algorithm detects suspected rubbish byplacements. An enforcer then looks at the video to see if it really is an incidental deposit. Then the corresponding images are viewed by an enforcer to see if the by-pitter is in the picture. After that, the enforcer can give the sideloader - if recognised by the enforcer - an administrative fine. This is what the citizen notices. Cameras are placed under the Mayor's Designation Order: https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/gmb-2021-464650.pdf
decision_making_process: Enforcement of Waste Regulation, no automated decisions
competent_authority: Controller is the municipality of The Hague.
objection_procedure: No, but the results of the algorithm are always assessed by a person. An objection can be made to a fine.
description: Camera takes image of a waste container and its immediate surroundings. Software - the algorithm - compares the footage with previous images. If an object appears in the image that remains stationary for an extended period of time, that is a 'hit' for a possible addition. Those camera images (and the previous few minutes) are flagged and reviewed by an enforcer to see if the updraft is recognisable in the image.
application_url: Het algoritme is ontwikkeld en geinstalleerd door de leverancier van het camerasysteem, Connection Systems. Daar is de documentatie op te vragen.
monitoring: There are no risks because there is always a person assessing the outcomes.
performance_standard: At the end of the project, it will be evaluated in total. Among others, the number of false positive recognition and false negative recognition by the algorithm.

name: Cyrb sound recognition
description_short: Algorithm that detects a sound and determines what kind of sound it is. The type of sound is recorded.
goal: This is a pilot project. The algorithm was developed to recognise sounds. In addition, it aims to get a picture of where, when and what types of noise are present. A third goal is to possibly act immediately if the type of noise or noise level gives cause to do so.
proportionality: There is no alternative; this is the simplest and least intrusive measurement.
lawful_basis: Municipal Act. Article 172 Enforcement of public order
source_data: Sound clips
methods_and_models: In evaluating the model, the confusion matrix is used and the categorical-crossentropy is used as a metric.
human_intervention: Yes. The sensor can be turned off in a simple way. This will be decided if there is no added value or if objections arise that need to be taken into account.
risks: The algorithm is trained on public datasets of similar sounds. Because these do not always sound the same and have the same characteristics (and nature) as the sounds captured on location, the algorithm could make errors in sound recognition. As the algorithm is only for imaging purposes, this does not pose any immediate risks for the citizens and entrepreneurs involved. There is no risk of privacy violation because the sound itself is not stored. The categorisation of the sound does not include aspects that could lead to bias, e.g. nationality.
impact: The results of the algorithm were validated with residents to investigate whether the perception of noise matches the measured values. If a citizen/visitor/business causes noise pollution or a disturbing type of noise (e.g. gunshot), the citizen will face enforcement or police.
decision_making_process: The algorithm is used to direct an enforcer to a situation where something might be wrong, judging by the type of noise. There is no automated decision-making.
competent_authority: The Hague municipality
objection_procedure: There is no formal objection procedure. There is always a human check of the outcomes. In the unlikely event that citizens wish to object, they can do so by making the objection known to the municipality.
description: The algorithm converts 4-second sound clips into spectrograms, visual representations of the sound. The spectrograms are images of 128x128 pixels in greyscale. These spectrograms are then classified by an image recognition algorithm into a number of categories, such as "stationary traffic", "music", "honking", etc. This image recognition model is a relatively small convolutional neural network of five layers. (Three convolutional layers followed by max-pooling and two fully connected layers). The model runs in python, using the Tensorflow library.
monitoring: Critical consideration will be given to whether the sensors actually provide the expected added value. Findings of citizens are welcome and will be taken into consideration
performance_standard: For the overall solution, effectiveness is examined. For this, it measures whether the signals were useful, the threshold values are right, the location of the microphone is right, enough follow-up can be done, etc.

name: Calculating the WOZ value
description_short: Determining and approving the WOZ value based on appraisal models and preparing an appraisal report. The status of 4Woz 2.0 is in production. In the municipality of The Hague, appraisal values will be determined with 4Woz for the first time in 2022. This valuation process is currently (November 2021) being designed. Currently, valuation is still done with similar valuation models within IBS (Integral Tax System), built by the municipality of The Hague itself.
website: De code wordt niet openbaar gepubliceerd. De applicatie 4Woz is een standaard WOZ-taxatiesysteem van het bedrijf 4Value, dat ook door andere gemeenten in Nederland wordt gebruikt.
goal: The 4Woz application supports in the valuation process for the implementation of the WOZ Act.  4Woz supports the management of property characteristics, the analysis of market data, the determination of appraisal values, the checking and approval of the appraisal values into (in IBS) WOZ values to be disposed of and the preparation of the appraisal report as substantiation of the WOZ value. In particular, the algorithms play a role in determining the appraisal values and preparing the appraisal report because these involve complex calculations and comparisons. The appraisal algorithm functions well when the value level is correct, the inter-value ratios are right and there is a reconciliation of the appraised values to the analysed market data. The appraisal report algorithm works well when appraisal reports make the appraised value plausible, e.g. by presenting all the property characteristics of the property itself, stating its own market data and (in the case of residential properties) referring to three comparable sold properties with a WOZ value.
proportionality: There is no better alternative to 4Woz's algorithms. On the contrary, 4Woz itself is currently seen as an alternative to a traditional way of valuing where individual valuations can be made outside the IBS valuation model. In a completely traditional way of working, individual, municipal valuers each make their own interpretation of property characteristics and market data into an appraisal value. A computerised valuation model that works according to algorithms generally helps to make the analysis of market data, valuation of properties and substantiation through a valuation report much more consistent and unambiguous. The frequency of annual valuations and WOZ decisions is only possible thanks to algorithms such as those included in 4Woz.
lawful_basis: The legal basis that makes working with algorithms/taxation models such as 4Woz necessary is the WOZ (Valuation of Immovable Property Act). Under this, the municipality of The Hague annually determines the value of all WOZ properties via a WOZ decision open to objection and appeal. The assessed value is substantiated with a valuation report that is available to interested parties. The municipality also implements the WOZ Act for its customers, including the National Tax Office and the Water Board. Data are supplied to the customers via the National Provision WOZ (LV WOZ).
source_data: The WOZ Act makes extensive use of basic registrations. The WOZ object is delimited on the basis of data on property recorded in the Basic Land Registry Register, BRK. And usage is based on natural and non-natural persons listed in the Basisregistratie Personen (BRP) and/or the Handelsregister (NHR). When delineating WOZ objects, the relationship is also made to premises and addressable objects from the Basic Register of Addresses and Buildings (BAG). Part of the tax application IBS also forms the Property Valuation Act (WOZ) basic register, which records the object, the interest (the tax liability) and the WOZ value. The WOZ sector model provides insight into the hundreds of data included in a tax application and valuation system such as 4Woz. It would go too far to write this out here. Two main groups of data are processed through the algorithm, First, these are object characteristics such as primary object characteristics (type of object, size, year of construction, outbuildings and the like), secondary object characteristics which are a qualification of e.g. location, maintenance, quality and appearance. The second group of data includes market data such as asking prices, purchase prices, rents, construction costs and land prices. These are mostly reduced to key figures. The algorithm then calculates the values of WOZ properties in components using object characteristics x key figures. The sum of the value of components is the assessed value, which is approved and delivered to IBS (Integrated Tax System) after verification.
methods_and_models: In fact, algorithms are very simple mathematical operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication and division when calculating appraisal values from object characteristics and unit prices. The same is true when preparing valuation reports. More complicated sub-processes such as coding and measuring object characteristics and classifying objects into groups and the like is still old-fashioned manual work. This also applies to setting the unit prices used for calculation. The fact that algorithms are nevertheless applied in the form of 4Woz has to do with the fact that nearly 300,000 WOZ objects with a multitude of WOZ sub-objects and object characteristics) are valued in an annual process. In doing so, the algorithm helps to do this in a consistent manner to ensure as much as possible that equal objects are treated equally.
human_intervention: Yes, certainly there is human intervention in the sense of the user of the application 4Woz. WOZ data managers take care of managing property characteristics in a consistent manner, WOZ valuers analyse market data in interaction with stakeholders (citizens and businesses). WOZ appraisers set up the models, which amounts to determining unit prices and setting the influence of object characteristics on the appraisal value. Finally, the outcome of the appraisal model is checked by WOZ appraisers before the WOZ values are determined. The 4Woz application is used in an annual process. In it, managing property characteristics and performing market analysis are continuous activities. After WOZ decisions are made in IBS within eight weeks after 1 January each year, 4Woz supports successively in a number of WOZ sub-processes. At first mainly in the handling of objections and appeals, in summer and autumn the emphasis is on the set-up of valuation models, in autumn the emphasis is on preliminary consultations with specific stakeholders and on large-scale checking of the quality of valuations. Within eight weeks of 1 January, the annual cycle is in principle completed with the re-adoption of the WOZ assessments. This is basically the way to freeze and formalise the outcomes of the algorithms. Until then, a WOZ assessor can continuously improve the WOZ assessment before it is determined as a WOZ value. The handling of objections is a formal moment to reconsider the outcome of the valuation model with the citizen or company.
risks: For automated valuation models, risks include, in particular, a poor quality of object characteristics, insufficient or inadequately analysed market data, the set-up of the valuation models with key figures and a poor verification process of appraised values. The outcomes of 4Woz's algorithms depend on the quality of property characteristics, proper analysis of market data and the proper design of the assumptions of the valuation models. Great importance is attached at the front end of this valuation process to the professionalism of the WOZ data managers for an unambiguous and complete registration of object characteristics. Similarly, importance is attached to craftsmanship of the WOZ valuer for proper market analysis, knowledge of the market, design and operation of the valuation models and verification of valuations. Through informal contact, many citizens and businesses are also able to provide information for the benefit of the valuation process and/or objection handling.
impact: The effect on the daily life of citizens and businesses is that the application 4Woz enables the municipality of The Hague to annually make a new, up-to-date WOZ valuation for all WOZ objects in The Hague and substantiate it with a valuation report. The WOZ assessments are sent annually to citizens and companies (on paper or digitally) together with a WOZ decision open to objection and appeal. This is communicated through local media, the website of the municipality of The Hague and MijnDenHaag.nl. The WOZ value of a house is public to a limited extent and can be consulted via wozwaardeloket.nl. Citizens and companies can request the assessment report of the WOZ objects of which they are interested parties (owner and/or user). Users of the WOZ value, such as the National Tax Office and the Water Board, use the WOZ value for taxation, among other things.
decision_making_process: The 4Woz application supports in the valuation process for the implementation of the WOZ Act. This is a statutory task assigned to all municipalities in the Netherlands. The purpose of the WOZ Act is to determine the value of immovable property in the municipality for the purposes of taxation by the national, regional and municipal authorities. In 4Woz the valuations are determined and approved by WOZ assessors. The WOZ values and appraisal reports are delivered to the IBS (Integral Tax System), which takes the decisions open to objection and appeal, called WOZ decisions. These, together with the assessments of municipal taxes, are notified to citizens and businesses within eight weeks of January 1 each year.
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague.
objection_procedure: An objection can be made to the outcome of the process in which the 4Woz algorithm is used. The outcome of the algorithm is the WOZ value determined by a WOZ decision open to objection and appeal.  Another outcome of the algorithm is an assessment report substantiating the WOZ value. According to the WOZ Act, the interested party (owner/user) of a WOZ assessment can submit a reasoned objection within six weeks after the date of the decision, pointing out incorrect data.  As part of the handling of the objection, the grievances are assessed and the data underlying the WOZ assessment including the WOZ value are corrected if necessary. The ruling on the objection is open to appeal. The interested party can also always address a question to the Tax Department of the municipality of The Hague. This can sometimes lead to ex officio adjustments.
description: One group of algorithms includes the computational rules whereby, based on property characteristics and unit prices set by the appraiser, the appraisal value is calculated in parts. A two algorithm is used to prepare residential property valuation reports based on a kind of penalty point system. Here, a legal requirement is that this appraisal report shows three properties with WOZ value and an analysed market data (purchase price, exceptionally a sample appraisal).
monitoring: The outcomes of 4Woz's algorithms depend on the quality of object characteristics, correct analysis of market data and correct design of the assumptions of the valuation models. Great importance is attached at the front end of this valuation process to the professionalism of the WOZ data administrators for an unambiguous and complete registration of object characteristics. Similarly, importance is attached to craftsmanship of the WOZ valuer for proper market analysis, knowledge of the market, design and operation of the valuation models and verification of valuations. Through informal contact, many citizens and companies are also able to provide information for the benefit of the valuation process and/or objection handling.
performance_standard: In the implementation of the WOZ Act, audit protocols drawn up by the Valuation Chamber as an example are used to assess the outcomes of the valuation process (with the algorithms of 4Woz, among others). The Valuation Chamber is part of the Ministry of Finance that supervises the implementation of the Valuation Act. As part of the application of the assessment protocols, market-level reconciliation is assessed on the basis of ratios and key figures, among other things. This is done for the entire municipality as well as for groups of properties and individual properties. It also looks at asking prices in relation to WOZ values (of properties for sale), at consistent value development compared to a previous value reference date, at the market development of sold/unsold properties, at findings from objection handling and, finally, the valuation reports are assessed.

name: Smartcity/ sound recognition
description_short: Algorithm that detects which sound can be seen in the spectrogram based on spectrograms. Under development, not yet active, no data shared yet.
website:
De Cyrb-sensoren zijn toegevoegd aan onderstaande kaart.
https://ddh.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=8531785e9a8c4450be8839385003f1bc
goal: The algorithm was developed to recognise sounds. In the current application, for sounds above a certain decibel level, it identifies what the nature of the loud noise was. This gives an insight into the kind of noises that cause nuisance. The algorithm aims to get an overall picture of where, when what types of noise nuisance are present so that further research can be done on them. The results of the algorithm are not intended as grounds for direct decisions or actions without verification of the results.
proportionality: There is no alternative to the noise recognition algorithm. The algorithm is an addition to sound level measurement.
lawful_basis: No legal basis has been chosen. As long as the system is not used, there is also no need to update the 2019 DPIA.
source_data: The algorithm processes only spectrograms that were in turn generated from self-recorded audio files.
methods_and_models: In evaluating the model, the confusion matrix is used and the categorical-crossentropy is used as a metric.
human_intervention: The algorithm can be stopped by shutting down the processes on the sensor. This can be done remotely by Cyrb or by the administrator by switching off the power to the sensor. No processes flow directly from the algorithm's outcomes.
risks: The algorithm is trained on public datasets of similar sounds. Because these do not always sound the same and have the same characteristics (and nature) as the sounds captured on location, the algorithm could make errors in sound recognition. As the algorithm only serves for imaging purposes, this does not directly pose risks for the citizens and entrepreneurs involved. The risk of data leakage (recorded sounds) has been overcome by not storing the sound on the device but performing sound recognition directly on the device.
impact: The effect of the algorithm's outcome: By better understanding the cause of noise nuisance experienced by citizens, the municipality can better perform its task in maintaining a pleasant comfortable outdoor space. Besides being able to identify the type of noise (noise recognition), the noise level (decibels) was also measured in a test setup. At present, no citizens are interacting with the algorithm. Two residents of the area where this algorithm was tested were involved for the duration of the test to investigate whether the intended concept application works. They gained insight into the decibel levels measured in the outdoor area through a dashboard (nb: the algorithm itself does not measure decibels). At these two residents' homes, a sensor was hung on their facade to verify what the noise levels are at their homes. Besides these two intensively involved residents, a larger event was organised during the summer of 2020 to inform visitors and residents of and on the promenade, during the Smart @Sea festival. Through publications in (local) newspapers, on websites of the municipality of The Hague and Province of South Holland, residents are informed about the various tests being carried out as part of the Living Lab Scheveningen programme. This test to gain insight into noise pollution and noise perception also falls within that programme. https://www.denhaag.nl/nl/in-de-stad/wonen-en-bouwen/ontwikkelingen-in-de-stad/ontwikkelingen-scheveningen-kust/nieuwe-uitvindingen-in-living-lab-scheveningen.htm
decision_making_process: The algorithm is not used for decision-making. The algorithm only determines which sound is visible in a spectrogram.
competent_authority: The Hague municipality is the Controller, Cyrb the Processor. There is no provider or recipient.
objection_procedure: There is no formal objection procedure. The algorithm recognises sounds in public spaces. No decisions are made on the basis of the algorithm that could prejudice individuals. Should citizens unexpectedly wish to object, they can do so by making the objection known via info@cyrb.nl.
description: The algorithm converts 4-second sound clips into spectrograms, visual representations of the sound. The spectrograms are images of 128x128 pixels with grey values. These spectrograms are then classified by an image recognition algorithm into a number of categories, such as "stationary traffic", "music", "honking", etc. This image recognition model is a relatively small convolutional neural network of five layers. (Three convolutional layers followed by max-pooling and two fully connected layers). The model runs in python, using the Tensorflow library.
performance_standard: No arrangements have been made to verify the quality of sound recognition. Incidentally, the algorithm itself indicates the degree of certainty with which a sound has been recognised.

name: Recognition axe placement ORACs
description_short: Digital scanning and categorisation of types of byplacements at Orac's.
goal: Exploit the technical development on image recognition in the operational process by using parking enforcement's scan cars. Image recognition can be a good addition to the various ways of detecting side placements, as scan cars are already driving around the city. The aim is to strengthen the MOR chain and speed up follow-up. Reduction on repeat notifications, duplicate notifications, manual actions and the follow-up time of clearing is -in addition to service to citizens- a significant improvement in business operations for the chain partners. With the application of scanning technology, the aim is to additionally feed the notification chain with -extension of- existing resources. The clearance of waste and its enforcement can potentially be followed up even faster.
proportionality: Yes, there are several initiatives to combat litter nuisance. This project is an addition in the approach and not an alternative.
source_data: Image captures of oracs.
human_intervention: A deskforce monitors the image recognition in particular to promote the self-learning effect of the applied artificial intelligence on automatic assignment to the correct waste category and follow-up information provision to the relevant chain partners. This process can be stopped at any time.
risks: There are risks related to storage of images, which have not yet been identified.
impact: - Additional placements are detected and removed faster (clean city); - The notifier is informed faster (better service), if a report is also detected by scanning technology.
decision_making_process:
The council passed a motion on 20 February 2020 in which the council called on the college to conduct a study on the deployment of scanning cars (RIS 304747), this study showed the technology was available. 
The college also wanted to investigate whether the data obtained from the scanning technology could be integrated with reports from the reporting system (so that together they form one source of information for planning the operation on the street) and/or the data could be used for information-driven work in capacity planning and policy-based approach to byplacements. The study was conducted and found that linking data can be achieved.
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague
objection_procedure: N/A
description: The scanning vehicles are provided with the exact locations (GPS coordinates) where the ORACs are located. This is used to scan and determine when overview photos should be taken. Nine photos are sent from each ORAC; 3 from the camera facing forward, 3 from the angled camera and 3 from the camera facing backwards. It does not matter whether the ORACs enter the field of vision of the cameras to the right or left of the scanning car. The analysis of the images is done centrally. It is determined for each ORAC whether it has been superimposed. If so, it is categorised according to categories determined by The Hague (bags, boxes, chemical, white/brown goods and other). An indication of the volume of the additional placement is also given.
monitoring: N/A
performance_standard: N/A

name: Algorithm data quality
description_short: Quality-Bot (Q-Bot) independently discovers existing and new patterns in the data. We use these as Quick Scan to estimate data quality and detect possible errors. Then, good patterns can be adopted as data quality rules to continuously monitor data quality.
goal: The purpose of the algorithm is to identify patterns to detect possible (structural) errors in data in order to translate them into quality rules. It is intended to feed the source owner with new insights about data quality. It is not intended to independently correct data.
proportionality: Yes, Q-bot brings focus to improving data quality. It helps data specialists identify and resolve errors or peculiarities in data in a targeted way.
lawful_basis: None, no personal data are processed.
source_data: Leasehold contracts, properties and land registry plots. These are linked.
methods_and_models: Self-built algorithm that uses various, existing machine learning algorithms. Various existing algorithms are applied to the data and results from them are collected. The in-house algorithm then selects which patterns are relevant and strong.
human_intervention: Yes, this is the core of the application.
risks: Control of risks lies with the municipality. The risks are limited because the algorithm does not make independent decisions. The bias is exclusively technical and has no impact on decision-making or citizens.
impact: The effect is indirect for citizens. The effect is direct for Hague employees who are supported to improve the quality of service to citizens. The quality of registration improves and with it the quality of service.
decision_making_process: Contributes to the data checking and correction process. The role of the algorithm is to make suggestions for improvement with the aim of making the data more accurate. Policy and decision-making remain with the source owner.
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague
objection_procedure: Yes by the employees' long lease, and that is precisely the intention.
description: The data is structured into views by the technical user. The analysis preferences and settings are then determined. After that, the algorithm autonomously searches for significantly strong patterns in the data. These are collected in a list. These are then evaluated for quality and relevance. The most strong patterns are selected. Finally, the patterns are applied again to the original data and it determines which are normal (regular) and which are anomalous (irregular) for each field. These are then marked green or red.
application_url: n.v.t., Phinion biedt dienst aan als een SaaS.
monitoring: Risks are managed through employee evaluation.
performance_standard: Performance is done through user evaluation. Employees decide which patterns they want to use and how good they are.

name: PDF to 3D objects (Vector data)
description_short: Retrieve building data such as area/size, type, layout, geometry (shape and location) from various types of drawings for use in (basic) registrations. The status of PDF2GIS is 'under development'. PDF2GIS is in the test phase of phase 1 flat drawing (of 3 phases).
type: The algorithms are both rule-based and, in due course, self-learning. Existing algorithms are used. These will be improved if possible. Corrections by the user of PDF2GIS feed the self-learning capability in the future, e.g. in drawing lines and reading text labels. For phase 2 construction drawings, training data will be built for the self-learning algorithm by annotating construction drawings themselves.
website: De code wordt niet openbaar gepubliceerd. De applicatie PDF2GIS wordt in opdracht van de gemeente Den Haag ontwikkeld door Coders Co. De businesscase en het intellectueel eigendom liggen bij de leverancier. PDF2GIS is geïnitieerd vanuit project Startup in Residence.
goal: The PDF2GIS application is designed to retrieve building data from subdivision drawings (phase 1), construction drawings (phase 2) and estate agent floor plans (phase 3). It involves the coherent retrieval of objects, relationships and attributes of objects such as property, residence object, building zone, level, space and the flat right, among others. Coherent acquisition benefits quality (including completeness, consistency and accuracy). Higher quality reduces queries and coordination problems between e.g. (basic) registrations. The application eventually replaces measuring in a paper drawing or in a digital drawing with e.g. Bluebeam (where existing lines are redrawn).  A data manager or geo-information manager operates the application and can intervene in each of 13 steps to make corrections. The data are used in (basic) registrations such as WOZ, BAG and in the future perhaps SOR (Cohesive Object Registration). The programme functions well when the quality of the data can measure up to manually collected data.
proportionality: There is no alternative to PDF2GIS's algorithms. In fact, PDF2GIS itself is seen as an alternative to a traditional way of collecting building data. In a traditional way of working, individual municipal employees each make their own interpretation of lines and text in order to deduce building data. This involves proportionally fewer consistent interpretations and proportionally more errors, e.g. in calibration. The strength of PDF2GIS is the ability to collect data that are currently still kept separately in different basic registries in a coherent way. Current practice is that data in four different registries (WOZ, BAG, BGT, 3D city model) are not maintained simultaneously and from different sources. This is comparatively expensive (differences in feedback etc.) and the quality is comparatively low (due to differences in time, accuracy, precision etc.). There are no other programmes with algorithms that can collect building data in coherence, using existing, known building data, such as in the system of basic registries or the WOZ registration.
lawful_basis: Under the BAG Act (about managing addresses and buildings data), among other things, the size of the residential object is measured, under the WOZ Act (about the valuation of immovable property) the size of building areas on building floors within the WOZ object. WOZ uses BAG and in The Hague, WOZ is also delegated source holder for area data in BAG (WOZ measures for BAG in order to use the same area data for every building municipality-wide).
source_data: Data in basic registries are used in the PDF2GIS algorithm. These include the WOZ (property valuation), BAG (addresses and buildings), BGT (large-scale topography) and BRK (land register) as data sources. The result of PDF2GIS is ideally processed to (basic) registrations WOZ and BAG, in the future to the SOR (coherent object registration). The algorithm processes a drawing (flat drawing phase 1, construction drawing in phase 2 and estate agent's floor plan in phase 3) together with known data from basic registrations. As far as possible, the processing results in data about buildings. These are the objects, relations and attributes as mentioned in information models of BAG (IMBAG), WOZ (IMWOZ) and the SOR.
methods_and_models: PDF2GIS uses algorithms such as text detection (EAST algorithm), text recognition (Tesseract OCR), line recognition (Hough Line Transform), polygon-shaping algorithms as well as algorithms for georeferencing (rubber-sheeting etc.), among others.
human_intervention: Yes, certainly there is human intervention in the sense of user of the algorithm PDF2GIS. Distilling building data from scanned (sometimes old, less legible) drawings is (still) too complex to leave 'blind' solely to an algorithm. Processing a drawing is done in 13 steps in phase 1. And in each step, the user is expected to make corrections if necessary. For the time being, the user also has to process the result himself in possibly decreasing (basic) registrations.
risks: There are no risks associated with working with PDF2GIS's algorithms. The biggest pitfall is working with a drawing that does not represent an actual situation. Employees working with PDF2GIS pay attention to this by studying visual material such as aerial photos. Moreover, the output of PDF2GIS eventually forms the input of a chain in which building data is validated and distributed. There is no question of bias, in the sense that the algorithm may produce a systematic difference in representativeness ('discriminates'). At most, algorithms may work better on drawings of common buildings (flats) and less well on unique buildings, requiring the user to make manual corrections more often.
impact: The effect on the daily life of citizens and businesses is that the PDF2GIS application provides data on residential and commercial buildings. This kind of data, such as size/area and geometry, is recorded in the basic BAG registration and used in the (basic) WOZ registration in the valuation process for the purpose of making WOZ decisions. A citizen or company can see the data itself via the bagviewer.kadaster.nl or the woz-waardeloket.nl. For a directly interested building owner/user, data can be shown in detail on a WOZ valuation report. Data may also be included in a Twin City nederlandin3d.nl/denhaag and, in due course, in the SOR (coherent object registration).
decision_making_process: PDF2GIS does not support a decision-making process. PDF2GIS is intended to play a role in primary processes in which building data are applied. Among other things, the management of basic registrations (including BAG on addresses and buildings) and the implementation of the Valuation of Immovable Property Act (WOZ). Indirectly, the data from PDF2GIS play a role in the levying of taxes by public authorities (via the size and the WOZ value that is partly based on the area/size).
competent_authority: There is no processing of personal data.
objection_procedure: It is possible to 'object' to the outcome of the process in which the algorithm PDF2GIS is used. Websites such as bagviewer.kadaster.nl and wozwaardeloket.nl show some basic basic building data. With the BAG, a feedback can always be submitted on the basis of reasonable doubt. For the WOZ, the interested party (owner/user) of a building can submit a reasoned objection (one can always ask a question) after receiving a WOZ assessment and a valuation report, pointing out incorrect data. As part of the objection (or as a question), this is assessed and corrected if necessary.
description: The main functions of the algorithms are: recognising and detecting text and lines, forming plane objects from lines, converting text into labels that give the planes meaning, delineating building objects and relating them to known data in the system of basic registries (o.a.o. WOZ, BAG, BGT (large-scale topography), BRK (land register)), georeferencing (fitting drawings to existing geometry), generating output in the form of csv and geojson formats for WOZ and BAG, among others.
application_url: Documentatie van relevante algoritmen is hier te vinden: https://paperswithcode.com/paper/east-an-efficient-and-accurate-scene-tekst; https://tesseract-ocr.github.io/tessdoc/Home.html; https://docs.opencv.org/4.5.3/d6/d10/tutorial_py_houghlines.html
monitoring: Risks are monitored with every drawing that is processed. It assesses whether the drawing matches reality. And the outcome of the algorithm is checked against known data of the building on drawing.
performance_standard: The performance of the algorithms in PDF2GIS is assessed based on craftsmanship of the users of the application. The user of the application PDF2GIS tests the output of PDF2GIS on the basis of craftsmanship and on the basis of already known data of the buildings on drawings. For the size/surface area of objects, measurement instructions based on NEN 2580 are a guideline for this. For accuracy of area data, criteria formulated in BAG and WOZ regulations are leading. In principle, drawings are fitted to buildings that have been measured using terrestrial surveying techniques with high accuracy (centimetres).

name: Predicting and preventing road accidents
description_short: Prediction model providing risk scores on road accidents based on a broad dataset of road characteristics and accidents.
goal: The purpose of the model is twofold. First, to develop effective road safety policies. Secondly, the model can be used to compare two or more designs on road safety scores in concrete projects.
proportionality: At the time, this was the only model examining correlations between accident rates and road, intersection or environment characteristics.
lawful_basis: Necessary for municipal policy.
source_data: www.ongevalrisico.nl https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1_Kt3_mMHhjH-KZgKJxmmqlf9rlRdJr9mgaUUBcGtBDU/edit?authuser=1#slide=id.p4 Including BGT, NWB and BRON
methods_and_models: Algorithm is XGBoost. Validation: AUC, ROC, confusion matrix, citizens' subjective reports on road safety.
human_intervention: Yes, advisory outcomes for weather experts. Model outcomes are never adopted 1 to 1.
risks: No data that can be traced back to personal level is explicitly linked. The outcomes are assessed by an expert before use.
impact: Specific to traffic engineers, citizens eventually see road modifications, fewer accidents (is goal).
decision_making_process: The model is a tool for prioritising road safety policies.  As such, it does not involve automated decision-making.
competent_authority: There is no question of working with personal data.
objection_procedure: The algorithm looks for a correlation between objectively determinable variables. This involves the correlation of recorded accidents and objectively observable data from the road or its surroundings. The user decides whether or not to draw a consequence from this. Therefore, there is no possibility to object to this.
description: 1 set of roads on which accidents did occur and 0 set of roads on which no accidents occurred. Algorithm uses 'number of accidents' as target variable (classification) and tries to find differences between properties 1 and 0 sets.
monitoring: By the expert.
performance_standard: No arrangements have been made for this.

name: Automatic traffic light control software
description_short: TLCGen is an application for creating/generating uniform, high-quality and manageable traffic control programmes for traffic lights.
goal: Designing control programmes for in traffic lights. This is designed with TLCGen. It works well if TLCGen generates the right control programme that complies with the laws and rules about traffic lights. And if the control programme is properly tuned for that particular intersection in terms of safe and smooth.
proportionality: No, there are no equally suitable alternatives. There are other generators of traffic control programmes available, however, for the average Hague intersection, they involve more manual work than TLCGen and therefore higher risk for the road manager and lower manageability.
lawful_basis: This follows from the statutory duty of the road authority and the Road Traffic Act.
source_data: These are data related to the physical layout of intersections and the traffic choices that follow. The physical characteristics of the intersection and the sequence distribution of traffic flows desirable for safe and smooth traffic flow.
methods_and_models: see website https://www.codingconnected.eu/software/tlcgen/
human_intervention: Human intervention is purely aimed at providing input to the control programme.
risks: There are no specific risks in terms of privacy issues around personal data. Bias does not play a role.
impact: When a citizen uses public space as a participant in traffic and then encounters the control programme created with TLCGen. The citizen notices this by the optimal tuning of the green phases of traffic lights.
decision_making_process: There is no real question of supporting a decision-making process. It is a primary government task of the municipality as road authority to safely organise and smoothly direct traffic.
competent_authority: There is no processing of personal data.
objection_procedure: no
description: TLCGen is an application for creating/generating traffic control programmes for traffic lights. It thus creates a control programme for an intersection, grafted to that location, that ensures vellige and smooth traffic flow. The input is formed by the physical characteristics of the intersection and the sequence distribution of traffic flows, in combination with laws, rules and traffic policy principles. The control programme to be created from the generator works with information from detection loops in the road and push buttons at traffic lights (which are ones and zeros), not with personal data.
monitoring: N/A
performance_standard: TLCGen is certified by the Statistic Committee of Talking Traffic (national partnership). This means we meet the highest standards.

name: Microsimulation models regulated intersections
description_short: COCON is the acronym for "COherent CONglomerate of traffic control software" and is the most widely used programme in the traffic control world within the Netherlands to determine the order in which traffic flows are handled at intersections (and what is and is not allowed at the same time). The outcome is input for the traffic control programme to be created for each intersection.
goal: Designing phase sequences of traffic lights.
proportionality: No alternatives have been considered. Within the traffic engineering community, this product is uncontroversial.
lawful_basis: This follows from the statutory duty of the road authority and the Road Traffic Act.
source_data: Anonymous data on traffic intensities is used in relation to how best to design an intersection controlled by traffic lights, taking into account the layout of lanes, drafting lengths, distribution of traffic movements.
methods_and_models: see website https://dtvconsultants.nl/producten-en-diensten/cocon-en-graphium/
human_intervention: Yes
risks: There are no specific risks in terms of privacy issues around personal data. Bias does not play a role.
impact: When a citizen uses public space as a participant in traffic, they indirectly come into contact with the outcomes of COCON calculations for intersections. Citizens notice this by the sequence distribution and being allowed to cross at the same time or not at the same time in the green phases of traffic lights.
decision_making_process: There is no real question of supporting a decision-making process, but a primary government task in relation to road safety namely the design of (safe) and optimally functioning intersections.
competent_authority: No mention of personal data.
objection_procedure: N/A
description: COCON is used to determine the so-called phase sequences at intersections with traffic lights. COCON supports and facilitates work for traffic experts. The software also performs (design) calculations for variant studies. When changing certain assumptions of an arrangement, the resulting effects become clear. COCON also allows traffic experts to advise each other: how can a traffic light-controlled intersection best be designed, taking into account lane layout, lane lengths, distribution of traffic movements, and so on.
monitoring: N/A
performance_standard: Supplier has a road user group and based on periodic reconciliation, they implement improvements.

name: Dynamic microsimulation models
description_short: The programme provides a visual representation of traffic flow on roads and intersections. Reality and possible future reality are sketched/simulated based on the inputs. With this computer model, options for road and intersection layouts and traffic arrangements can be compared and thus help with advice and choices.
goal: It is intended as a tool for road manager tasks to adequately implement, possibly improve and substantiate choices.
proportionality: This is the most widely used and proven microsimulation package for traffic management. There is no reason to use anything else.
lawful_basis: N/A The legal basis lies in proper implementation of the Road Traffic Act. It is an auxiliary tool for the work of the road authority.
source_data: Anonymous traffic data (numbers of vehicles, cyclists etc. per hour/time), road layout, traffic control programme settings are used.
methods_and_models: see website www.ptvgroup.com
human_intervention: The results are input for further traffic analysis.
risks: There are no specific risks in terms of privacy issues around personal data. Bias does not play a role.
impact: The citizen does not notice anything directly from the programme. Ultimately, the citizen as a traffic participant notices something of the choices made by the municipality as road administrator, partly on the basis of results of simulations, for traffic handling/ a good flow.
decision_making_process: The programme is used as an aid in (administrative) decision-making on proposed road and/or intersection redesign and analysis of the operation of intersection traffic controls. Consideration is then given to the consequences of the redesign and/or the control programme in terms of traffic flow.
competent_authority: There is no personal data, only traffic data, road data and traffic light data.
objection_procedure: no
description: The programme provides a visual representation of the expected traffic flows given the intended road layout and traffic light settings and the expected traffic flows.
monitoring: Through the user groups.
performance_standard: There are user groups of road authorities with which the supplier periodically coordinates to make any improvements.

name: Traffic model accessibility control
description_short: It is a traffic model to provide city-wide insight into, objectify and thus support the coordination and planning of activities (construction works, road works and events) on the network Bereikbaarheidsregie (the Hague's main traffic network) so as to safeguard Hague's Accessibility as much as possible.
goal: The aim of the model is to see the impact on traffic flow of a single activity or the relationship between multiple activities in a modelled and abstracted environment.
proportionality: Yes, but after a market consultation, nothing appeared to exist that met the demand. This model was newly developed for the Hague municipality by the market.
lawful_basis: N/A
source_data: Initial use was made of the V-MRDH model (HB matrix, route choices and intensities) supplemented with anonymous data from the head-end loops (zeros and ones) of 50 regulated intersections.
methods_and_models: N/A
human_intervention: The model is fed with data by an employee after which it can start calculating. The model is used as an analysis for interpreting traffic flows due to activities. The output is weighted in relation to discussions with initiators.
risks: There are no specific risks in terms of privacy issues around personal data. Bias does not play a role.
impact: A citizen does not directly interact with the algorithm. When a citizen uses public space as a participant in traffic and there are diversions, the citizen notices that the algorithm has been used to arrive at the best possible diversion with the least possible inconvenience.
decision_making_process: The output of the model is used to substantiate the issuing of a positive decision for a construction work, roadwork or event with impact on the Hague main traffic network in the Urban Accessibility Consultation (SBO). As such, it forms input for the consent decision.
competent_authority: There is no processing of personal data.
objection_procedure: N/A
description: This is an internally used model serving as input for discussions with the initiators of construction works, road works and events to take measures to ensure adequate traffic flow as well. It is an objective calculation to support the traffic engineering test for potential bottlenecks created by activities in the city (construction works road works and events). This model provides an estimate of where, given these activities and traffic flows, there may be bottlenecks. This provides input for coordinating with the initiators of the activities so that the (diversion) routes continue to function adequately. The output (nuisance) is qualified in terms of the number of people inconvenienced, travel time delays, waiting times, etc.
monitoring: N/A
performance_standard: No specific arrangements have been made to test the algorithm. A management and maintenance contract has been agreed with the supplier.

name: Regional traffic model: V-MRDH
description_short: The V-MRDH is a traffic model in the software Omnitrans (developer is DAT-Mobility, Deventer). The algorithm calculates the amount of trips (car, public transport and bicycle) based on input data such as networks and demographic data. The model is used, internally at The Hague, at other municipalities and at traffic engineering consultancies.
goal: The amount of traffic on the road due to a plan is calculated. The plan can be a new road or the construction of a number of houses. The model calculates the amount of traffic in outline form, meant to compare scenarios (variants).
proportionality: There is a traffic model for the entire MRDH to calculate future situations. When a study also involves national roads, cooperation is often established with RWS because RWS has models for traffic on national roads.
lawful_basis: Input is necessary for municipal policy.
source_data: Numbers of inhabitants and jobs from CBS. Plans from all relevant road authorities, national, municipal and provincial. Existing and future networks are also input for the calculations.
methods_and_models: The algorithms in the model belong to the standard software of the software's producer DAT-Mobility, Deventer.
human_intervention: Results of the model are always analysed by specialists.
risks: Results of the model are always analysed by specialists.
impact: Citizens never face a direct outcome of a traffic model calculation.
decision_making_process: A calculation is used to make or substantiate mobility policies (mobility here is the movement of people and goods). The algorithm never directly produces a decision.
competent_authority: There are no personal data.
objection_procedure: There is never any question of that. Within projects, people can discuss the outcomes of the model. The outcome of the model is used to inform an opinion.
description: The Hague is divided into 1,000 zones, each with an average of about 500 inhabitants. Those residents make on average about 4 trips per day, divided between the motives of work, business, education, shopping and social-recreational. The model estimates the total number of trips and the distribution between car, public transport and bicycle. The destination is based on the distance people are willing to travel on average. The relative attractiveness of car, public transport and bicycle determines the ratio between these three modes. The model is of the gravity principle: a closer destination has greater appeal than a destination far away.
application_url: Verkeersmodel | MRDH Metropoolregio Rotterdam Den Haag.
monitoring: Results of the model are always analysed by specialists.
performance_standard: No agreements and no monitoring applicable.

name: Scan car license plate recognition
description_short: The purpose of the algorithm is to automatically scan license plates for the purpose of parking enforcement and environmental zone enforcement.
goal: The purpose of the algorithm is to recognise license plates of vehicles that are in violation for after-tax parking tax and Penalty Environmental Zone (Mulder Act) respectively.
proportionality: No, this is in addition to manual enforcement.
lawful_basis: Municipal ordinances for tax parking enforcement and enforcement Environmental zones.
source_data: RDW, Licences/permits, GBA, National Parking Register
methods_and_models: Algorithm rests with suppliers. Municipality purchases services and has no substantive knowledge of how the algorithm works.
human_intervention: Through the intervention of a BOA (yes/no naheffing/fine or. yes/no admissible/founded objection). This process and information flow via the BOA (investigating officer) on duty. The BOA checks whether the license plate has been properly scanned before issuing a fine.
risks: Procurement of services from ISO-certified suppliers. Algorithms remain vested in the suppliers. A processor agreement and DPIA are in place to minimise risks to the municipality and citizens.
impact: A citizen encounters the outcome of the algorithm when a violation occurs - Detailed information page at www.denhaag.nl
decision_making_process: The algorithm supports the process to determine whether a car is parked incorrectly (Fiscal Parking Enforcement) and to determine whether a car/truck is driving incorrectly in a certain area (Environmental Zones Enforcement).
competent_authority: Municipality of The Hague
objection_procedure: Yes, respectively Objections Procedure Parking Enforcement and idem Environmental Zones.
description: A camera scans license plates. The algorithm combines data from the RDW/ permits, GBA and National Parking Register based on predefined rules (parameters) to determine whether there is wrong parking or unjustified driving in an Environmental Zone. Algorithm rests with suppliers. Municipality purchases service and has no direct involvement in or substantive knowledge of how the algorithms work.
application_url: Verwerkersovereenkomsten en de (duur van de) contracten die de gemeente sloot met de leveranciers. De gemeente bezit geen uitgebreide documentatie over de toegepaste algoritmes.
monitoring: Through the intervention of a BOA (yes/no naheffing/fine or. yes/no admissible/founded objection). This process and information flow through the on-duty BOA (investigating officer).
performance_standard: No specific performance of the algorithm has been agreed. Service performance by the supplier is discussed periodically.

name: Wmo forecasting model
description_short: The Wmo forecasting model provides a prediction of the number of unique users and costs of Wmo with a six-year forecast horizon. Predictions are made at district level for both the Wmo total and sub-products of the Wmo (Help with Household, Support at Home and Assistive Technology and Services).
goal: The algorithm was developed because the municipality wants to have more insight into the use and costs of Wmo in the coming years. The population of The Hague is growing and ageing, as a result of which the use of Wmo is also expected to increase. The question is by how many people and in which districts of The Hague and for which Wmo facilities? The forecasting model answers these questions.
proportionality: No alternatives were considered to achieve the goal.
lawful_basis: There is no legal basis for the forecasting model, but the municipality is responsible for implementing the Wmo and the model allows the municipality to better anticipate expected developments and better support citizens.
source_data: Only open data was used, namely the file Kerncijfers Wijken en Buurten CBS and the file Wmo-cliënten; type maatwerkarrangement CBS.
methods_and_models: The model is a regression model. The performance of this model is measured by the measures RMSE, MAE and MAPE. These are measures that variously determine how large the prediction error is.
human_intervention: There is no automated system. The insights from the prediction model can only be used through human intervention and with the context knowledge and experience of employees involved.
risks: The risks of the algorithm were identified in advance and during the construction of the prediction model. Because the prediction model does not make statements about individuals but about the use of facilities in neighbourhoods, there was no risk that the results from the model could violate the privacy of specific individuals.
