Furthermore, we only worked with neighbourhoods that were sufficiently large (more than 100 inhabitants) and where enough people used the Wmo (more than 100 users). One reason for this is that it does not allow for disclosure. That is, by combining characteristics, we cannot identify who the potential users of Wmo facilities are. Furthermore, when building the model, we weighed up together with the privacy officer which variables could and could not be included from a privacy perspective. Here, the AVG was always the starting point. In addition, explainability of the model and the results is a relevant and decisive criterion. Finally, Utrecht University's The Ethical Data Assistant was used to identify possible ethical problems in advance. This led to the drafting of an ethical framework. The question of what role bias plays in the use of the algorithm is far too general a question, as there are many forms of bias. If it is bias aimed at specific population groups, it does not play a role in this model. We are not looking for specific individual people with specific characteristics, but want to estimate the use of Wmo in the whole neighbourhood and for all of The Hague.
impact: The forecasting model makes no statements about (chances of) individual citizens and models have been chosen that are explainable. This means that, as a municipality, we do not use models for which it is difficult to determine how the model arrived at a particular outcome (so-called Black Box models). The Wmo predictive model in no way replaces the knowledge and skills of our consultants and implementation. The tool is not intended for them, but mainly for policy and making and substantiating policy choices for the longer term. It is precisely through the knowledge of the Wmo Predictor that we can anticipate in time and continue to better support all individuals.
decision_making_process: The insights from the Wmo forecasting model support policy and implementation in answering tactical and strategic questions. These are questions and topics that are relevant in the longer term (e.g. 5 to 10 years). The model is not intended to answer operational questions (short-term issues) and does not involve automated decisions.
competent_authority: The Wmo prediction model does not use person characteristics.
dpia: The Wmo prediction model does not use person characteristics.
objection_procedure: Given the nature of the model, this is not regulated.
description: A regression model is used to estimate the relationship between Wmo use and predictors. This involves searching for the characteristics with the smallest prediction error (determined using the measures: RMSE, MAE and MAPE). The characteristics best able to predict Wmo use are used for forecasting. Forecasts are made within a prediction interval of 80 per cent.
monitoring: If it is necessary to build/train a new model, the privacy officer will be involved in the choice of features and an entirely new model will also revisit the ethical framework.
performance_standard: The model is updated annually. Forecasts from the old model are compared with forecasts from the new model and compared with realisations.

name: Model from Assistance to Work
description_short: Algorithm that can identify target groups within the group of people on welfare based on characteristics. The goal is: tailored services to work or participation.
goal: The aim was to be able to determine an appropriate offer for people on welfare to work or participation pathways based on characteristics.
proportionality: The standard service is for consultants to make service choices based on interviews and data. Algorithm-based advice could complement this.
lawful_basis: The legal basis is implementation of the statutory task Participation Act.
source_data: Assistance data, data on reintegration and participation pathways, on debt assistance and self-reliance. The output is not used as input in any other automated process.
methods_and_models: Data analysis using Excel and R. Decision tree. Cluster algorithm. Text mining.
human_intervention: The outcome of the algorithm will always be an advice to the consultant and can be overridden by the consultant at any time. Processes of which the algorithm is a part are performed manually by individuals and not by a system based on the algorithm. These processes can be stopped at any time by the management or manager of the Plus 500 programme.
risks: A DEDA track was conducted (The Ethical Data Assistant) to recognise potential ethical issues. A DPIA was also carried out to recognise privacy risks.  During development of the algorithm, the project group is monitoring the risks. Should the algorithm be ready and implemented, additional monitoring of risks will be set up. Deliberate avoidance of bias and attention to inclusion will remain a focus of the operation.
impact: The algorithm was a one-off manual analysis. It is too early to say exactly how usage, risk management and communication would be shaped.
decision_making_process: The algorithm could have helped determine which citizens on welfare would benefit from certain services provided by the municipality. It involves advising the counsellor. Decision-making is not automated. All citizens on welfare receive services, no one is excluded.
competent_authority: The Hague municipality is the data controller. One-off work was done with a supplier and a processing agreement was concluded.
objection_procedure: The algorithm is not finalised. Anyway: the consultant speaks to the candidate and includes the outcome of the algorithm in the conversation. Based on this conversation, a follow-up process is agreed.
description: By analysing welfare files, a one-off pilot was used to identify the hard and soft characteristics of benefit recipients that had contributed to their outflow to work in the past. These characteristics were detected in the pool of benefit recipients and these citizens were invited for "the good talk" in an accelerated manner, so that they were dependent on benefits for as short a time as possible. This analysis only determined when a benefit recipient was invited, eventually everyone received an invitation to that interview. Since this pilot, the algorithm has been further developed with the aim of extending it so that tailor-made services can be offered more broadly.
monitoring: The algorithm has not entered production. If it had entered production, the algorithm's outcomes would be evaluated regularly to recognise any biases. Also, how the algorithm is applied by the consultant would then be evaluated.
performance_standard: First, it determines whether distinctive customer segments are possible with the available data. It then tests whether certain segments have a higher probability of outflow to work and whether there are other key focus areas for customised services. The algorithm functions well if it increases the probability of outflow to work or provides better services towards participation.

name: Focus on undermining
description_short: Several analyses are carried out in the Focus on Undermining project, see also website www.zichtopondermijning.nl. Work is ongoing to add insights and (new) analyses.
goal: In the analyses carried out for the Insight into Undermining dashboard, algorithms are regularly applied. Sometimes these are very simple algorithms. After all, where calculation rules are applied, in a strict sense there is already an algorithm. More methodologically complex algorithms are also used, such as a decision tree algorithm in the analysis of young recruitment and subgroup discovery in the group analysis of those involved in suspicious transactions. For the Focus on Undermining dashboard, algorithms are never applied to offer insights or draw conclusions at the level of individual addresses, companies, households or individuals. Individual data are pseudonymised and outcomes are always aggregated. Each analysis on the dashboard is described in detail in the In-depth Information section. There it is explained which analysis methods are applied, whether these are algorithms, which choices were made and which characteristics of addresses, companies, households or individuals were considered. Migration background is used in this dashboard as a characteristic in descriptive statistics of groups of households or persons only if there is sufficient justification for it. It is not used as a characteristic in classification algorithms applied to households or persons.
proportionality: The intended results and insights can only be achieved by working with CBS microdata within the frameworks of the CBS Act. For that reason, the City Deal 'Focus on Undermining' was drafted and signed in 2017 for that purpose. See also: https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/stcrt-2017-48699.html
lawful_basis:
Processing for scientific and historical research, statistical purposes and archiving in the public interest are always considered compatible with the original collection purpose. But even if they are not further processing, personal data may be processed for these purposes, provided the requirements in the Regulation are met. The Regulation requires that appropriate safeguards be put in place for the protection of the rights and freedoms of data subjects. Those safeguards must, among other things, ensure that technical and organisational measures are in place to process as little personal data as possible, such as pseudonymisation or anonymisation. 
The processing of personal data for the purpose of the analyses to be carried out will be carried out in compliance with the Personal Data Protection Act (Wbp) and, with effect from 25 May 2018, the General Data Protection Regulation (AVG) and the General Data Protection Regulation Implementation Act as well as, depending on the nature of the personal data to be processed, other relevant legal provisions relating to the protection of personal data, such as the Police Data Act (Wpg), the Judicial and Criminal Records Act (Wjsg) and the Central Statistics Office Act (CBS Act).
source_data: Because multiple algorithms are used, this is difficult to list in one field. CBS uses the BRP, BAG, WOZ, Kadaster.
methods_and_models: See previous comment, depends on type of analysis
human_intervention: Yes, before an analysis outcome is made public, CBS checks the insight for disclosure risk.
risks: The CBS needs significant oversight of the entire project and watches out for disclosure risks, among other things.
impact: There is no day-to-day impact for citizens. The analyses from the City Deal are intended to identify trends and patterns of undermining crime, they are not used in individual cases. Proceeds from analyses are shared publicly via a dashboard. The data are mostly historical (relate to previous years) and are not real-time
decision_making_process: The results of the analyses (and thus algorithms) are not used directly for decisions in individual cases, at most as input for policy choices at a higher level of abstraction.
competent_authority: The processing of personal data for the purpose of the analyses to be carried out will be carried out in compliance with the Personal Data Protection Act (Wbp) and, with effect from 25 May 2018, the General Data Protection Regulation (AVG) and the General Data Protection Regulation Implementation Act as well as, depending on the nature of the personal data to be processed, other relevant legal provisions relating to the protection of personal data, such as the Police Data Act (Wpg), the Judicial and Criminal Records Act (Wjsg) and the Central Statistics Office Act (CBS Act).
objection_procedure: N/A
monitoring: All research questions are submitted to the CBS ethics committee before a research question is considered by an analyst.
performance_standard: N/A, given the role/utilisation of algorithms within the Zicht op Ondermijning project.

name: Reinvestigations Benefit recipients
description_short:
In Rotterdam, everyone participates. Even residents who do not have sufficient income or assets of their own. They usually receive benefits from the municipality. The Work & Income (W&I) cluster of the municipality of Rotterdam regularly examines and assesses whether the benefits residents receive are legitimate and still fit their situation.  

The municipality of Rotterdam has not been using the algorithm that supports selection for these reexaminations since early 2022. Our exploration of an improved model also showed that it is not possible to develop an algorithm that fits within our policy at the moment.
goal: The model made a prediction for the probability of illegality or, on the contrary, lawfulness, by looking at the data known in the records of citizens for whom a lawfulness investigation took place in previous years. That conclusion may have been that the benefit was granted lawfully; or that the previously granted benefit did not match the actual situation (unlawfulness). Based on this historical data, a prediction can be made about the probability of lawfulness or unlawfulness among current benefit recipients. That prediction is thus made on the basis of the data of current benefit recipients known in our records. The outcome of the model is a 'risk estimation number' that varies between 0 (high probability of legitimacy) and 1 (high probability of illegality). The benefit recipients with the highest risk estimation number are invited for an investigative interview, unless, for example, a legitimacy investigation has already taken place recently. The number of benefit recipients to be invited is redetermined annually on the basis of the risk estimation model. The model is redeveloped every year, as new investigation data become available each year. Thus, information from recent investigations into legality are always taken into account when developing a new model. The municipality of Rotterdam has not been using this algorithm since early 2022. Our exploration of an improved 'risk model' showed that it is currently not possible to develop an algorithm that fits our policy.
proportionality: The model does not rule on legality or illegality: the investigation required for that ruling is always carried out by a staff member. That examination is always done in the same way, whether the benefit recipient is invited on the basis of the risk assessment model or one of the other selection methods. The algorithm does not process information that could directly lead to discrimination, such as nationality, age or health status. The municipality has explored using information in the model that may be related to nationality or origin, such as language knowledge to avoid the risk of discrimination or bias. Exploration has shown that this is not currently possible and the development of an improved model has been discontinued.
source_data: Rotterdam City Council regularly investigates and assesses whether people receiving benefits are still entitled to them. Benefit recipients may therefore be invited for an investigative interview. To determine who gets an invitation, the municipality uses various selection methods. One of these is a risk estimation model with a predictive algorithm. This justification provides an overview of the main digital data sources used in the development and in the application of the algorithm. The risk estimation model uses two data sources: 1. Socrates: Socrates is the benefit administration system. In it, the amount of benefit provided is determined and recorded. This system includes data on, for example, the housing/living situation of the benefit recipient. 2. RWM/Raak: RWM/Raak is the system in which data on the reintegration of jobseekers are recorded. It concerns data on the competences and qualities of the jobseeker that are important for his chances on the labour market, and the routes that are set out to increase the chances of employment. It concerns information that is recorded within the municipality in the context of the implementation of the Participation Act. There is no link with other databases.
human_intervention: The risk assessment model does not determine whether a person is receiving benefits lawfully or unlawfully. With the model, however, part of the determination is which benefit recipients are invited for an investigative interview. An expert income consultant from the Work & Income Department of the Municipality of Rotterdam conducts this investigation. After carrying out the investigation, the income consultant determines whether the jobseeker's benefit has been granted lawfully or unlawfully and whether it still fits the situation in which the jobseeker finds himself.
risks: To determine the risk of an algorithm, the municipality of Rotterdam uses an established classification model. The risk estimation model has been classified as a high-risk algorithm. The municipality therefore takes extra security measures. These include measures to ensure that there is proper supervision of the development and use of the model. These include specifically looking at the ethical risks and having an external oversight committee look at the design and use of the model. This committee is expected to be in place by early 2022. If there is an algorithm in the high-risk category, a human review is part of the work process in which the algorithm in question is used. The risk of bias is reduced because the risk estimation model is only used to determine who receives an invitation to a research interview. The algorithm does not determine whether someone is lawfully or unlawfully receiving benefits. This is done by income consultants from the W&I department. They investigate the situation extensively, together with the benefit recipient. After all, providing benefits is tailor-made and is done on an individual level.
impact: For a family living on little money, an invitation to an interview is already very exciting, as it could have consequences.
description: In Rotterdam, everyone participates. Even residents who do not have sufficient income or assets of their own. They usually receive benefits from the municipality. The cluster Work & Income (W&I) of the municipality of Rotterdam regularly examines and assesses whether the benefit that residents receive is legitimate and still appropriate to their situation. Benefit recipients may therefore be invited for an investigative interview. To determine who receives an invitation, the municipality uses various selection methods, including a risk assessment model. This model helps the municipality to estimate in which benefit recipients there is a high probability that the benefit does not (no longer) fit the situation of the benefit recipient (illegality). This has two advantages. It helps the municipality avoid extensive recoveries. In addition, benefit recipients for whom the probability of illegality is deemed low are less likely to be invited for an investigation interview. The risk estimation model uses a predictive algorithm. This algorithm uses data that the W&I cluster needs to perform its legal duties and to be able to provide the benefit. This includes data such as the amount of the benefit, the family situation, but also competences and qualities of the jobseeker, which are important for their chances on the labour market. The municipality only uses data from its own administration. The risk estimation model is only used to select benefit recipients for an interview. Based on the model, no statements are made about the lawful or unlawful provision of benefits. An employee of the Rotterdam municipality assesses the right to a benefit, as this depends on many factors and is also custom-made. The algorithm therefore does not make or prescribe decisions. The model is redeveloped every year because new survey data become available every year. Thus, information from recent studies on legality have always been taken into account when developing a new model. The municipality of Rotterdam has not been using this algorithm since early 2022. Our exploration of an improved 'risk model' showed that it is currently not possible to develop an algorithm that fits our policy.

name: TVL Risk model
description_short: The algorithm is used to make an automated risk assessment for all Applications for Fixed Chargesgemoetkoming, prior to automated or manual granting and payment of the advance.
goal: With the deployment of the algorithm, decision making is accelerated so that as many entrepreneurs as possible can receive liquidity support on time. The algorithm speeds up decision-making for granting relief and it provides risk interpretation for manual flow.
proportionality:
In the TVL, the risk model (algorithm) is used to automatically check all applications against the scheme criteria and make a risk classification for improper use. Prior to the advance payment and before the final determination of the grant. This speeds up the decision-making chain so that entrepreneurs can receive liquidity support as soon as possible. 
The deployment of the risk model enables RFO to make positive decisions on large numbers of subsidy applications in a very short time, so that entrepreneurs who need fixed expense support quickly during corona lockdowns can get it. Furthermore, the risk model enables RFO to process only positive decisions without the intervention of an employee, allowing employees to assess the remaining decisions more quickly. A similar outcome without the deployment of the risk model was assessed as not feasible during the preparation of the scheme: it would require a large-scale scaling-up of specialised staff, which cannot be organised at short notice. Even if it had succeeded, the turnaround times for entrepreneurs would have been much longer without the risk model.
lawful_basis: Legal basis TVL scheme: https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0044808/2022-10-19 The House of Representatives was informed about the largely automated implementation through the following progress report, see: https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten/kamerstukken/2021/03/22/voortgangsrapportage-tvl
contact_email: Voor contact over deze registratie neem contact op met RVO via het contactformulier; https://www.rvo.nl/onderwerpen/over-ons/contact/formulier onder vermelding van Bedrijf/instelling,  Covid-19: TVL/TOGS/ATE, of Overheidsorganisatie, Covid-19 regelingen.
human_intervention: With each new TVL round (application phase as well as determination phase), the risk model is adjusted and resubmitted for approval to an interdepartmental advisory committee (rolling review), which advises the general director of RFO on the application of the risk model. Once it has been put into use, the risk model determines the qualitative and quantitative risk of each application; these factors together form the overall risk category. Category 1 is awarded automatically, from Category 2 10% falls out to manual and the rest is awarded automatically. In case the algorithm identifies an application as high risk, Category 3, it falls out to a manual check by an employee. For example, because the amount is high, the application is incomplete, or there are indications of abuse or improper use. The application is then readied for human review, and the algorithm gives advice to the clerk on what to look out for, such as data that is incomplete or contradictory. This can be useful: the advice helps the clerk get a quick picture of the situation. The clerk then reviews the entire application. The clerk can then approve or reject applications, possibly after a further request for information. A negative decision (no or lower grant) therefore does not follow from the risk model but always from an employee's assessment. In case of deviation from the customer request and for subsidy amounts above a certain limit, this is always done via the 4-eye principle.
impact: The use of the algorithm in TVL applications ensures that entrepreneurs' applications can be processed quickly and efficiently. The majority of entrepreneurs have the money in their account quickly. The algorithm ensures that low-risk applications can be granted or determined immediately in an automated manner. When an application fails manual verification, an employee has to assess the application. In that case, it takes longer for a decision on the allowance to be made, resulting in the money being in the entrepreneur's account later.
decision_making_process: TVL version
objection_procedure: Each TVL decision contains an objection clause explaining how an entrepreneur can object to the mandated person's decision, see https://www.rvo.nl/subsidies-financiering/bezwaar-maken for the objection procedure.
description: RFO deploys an algorithm to support the assessment of applications from entrepreneurs. This algorithm tests whether an application meets the conditions set by the minister. This is done with the help of a risk model: when an application arrives at the RFO, an estimate is made whether the entrepreneur is actually entitled to the allowance. For this, the RFO compares, for example, the applicant's declared information with other data known to the government, such as declarations to the tax authorities. An application is automatically approved if the algorithm classifies the application as low risk, for example because the amount the applicant claims is low and there are no indications of abuse or improper use. In that case, no more employee is involved. The entrepreneur then has the money in his account within a week. If an application is deemed high-risk by the algorithm, for instance because it involves a high amount or because there are doubts about the declared turnover, a manual check follows, resulting in an extra processing time of two to three weeks on average - maximised to the Awb decision deadlines. In figures, 49% were decided within 1 week of receipt, 71% within 3 weeks and 96% within 8 weeks. Where abuse or improper use has been found in a previous application, future applications will always be checked manually. Even when an application is complex so that it cannot be assessed automatically, a manual check will follow. The application will then be assessed by an employee, who may ask the entrepreneur for additional information. The clerk then decides whether to grant or reject the request. In case of deviation from the customer request and for grant amounts above a certain limit, this is always done through the 4-eye principle.

name: Telephone Collection (Wahv Act)
description_short: One of the most important social tasks CJIB faces is socially responsible debt collection. CJIB wants to support people as much as possible in meeting their payment obligations and prevent an unnecessary increase in debt among citizens. CJIB has therefore invested in recent years in a personalised approach to debtors and making it possible to make payment arrangements for people who cannot pay (immediately). To this end, CJIB has developed additional services and possibilities. The algorithm 'Telephone collection (Wahv Act)' supports one of these developed services. If a person receives a second reminder for a traffic fine and does not pay it (in full), he or she can be called by a CJIB employee. The algorithm predicts for which person a personal conversation over the phone is more likely to be the appropriate means of making a payment or reaching a payment appointment. This creates direct and personal contact and a suitable solution is sought together. In this way, CJIB aims to prevent traffic offenders from having to deal with a bailiff. For more information or for questions, please visit: https://www.cjib.nl/telefonisch-innen.

name: Web application Impact monitor Bridge opening
description_short: The Impact Monitor Bridge Openings is a decision-support web application that supports bridge operators in choosing the optimal time for a bridge opening. Traffic flow and emissions (carbon footprint) are taken into account. The application is equipped to predict traffic flow up to 21 minutes ahead in combination with up-to-date (real-time) traffic information.
type:
Predictive
The app is a real-time forecasting model that can predict up to 21 minutes in the future the inconvenience to road traffic due to a bridge opening (vehicle loss hours based on traffic intensity and traffic congestion model)
category: Traffic and waterways, Bridge monitoring system (BMS), Traffic flow Prediction, Deep learning, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Traffic congestion model, Data science, Forecasting model, Real-time, API
status: The Impact Monitor Bridge Openings pilot phase has ended. Three bridges are currently included in the Bridge Openings Impact Monitor: the Coenecoop Bridge (Waddinxveen), the Lamme Bridge (Leiden) and the Kruithuis Bridge (Delft). During the pilot, the application was tested and evaluated with a select group. It is currently being determined how the algorithm will become part of the vessel tracking system.
goal: The Impact Monitor Bridge Openings is built to support bridge operators in choosing the optimal time for a bridge opening. The application is equipped to predict traffic volumes up to 21 minutes ahead in combination with up-to-date vessel traffic information. The Impact Monitor Bridge Openings is adapted to the behaviour and work process of bridge operators. In the application, the bridge operator sees 3 time slots of 7 minutes at a bridge. The app calculates in which of the three time periods a bridge opening causes the least inconvenience to road traffic. The bridge operator then makes the decision on when and how long to open the bridge.
proportionality: The algorithm does not process any personal data (such as age, gender, income, health, and so on). The information is in no way traceable to a natural person. Moreover, there is always still human intervention and the bridge operator still ultimately decides the best time to open a bridge. The algorithm itself is only decision-supportive.
lawful_basis: South Holland province has an important role in traffic flow within the region and is responsible for managing, maintaining and operating more than 100 bridges in South Holland. See among others: https://lokaleregelgeving.overheid.nl/CVDR431299/1
contact_email:
Voor vragen en opmerkingen kan je terecht bij: digitaalzuidholland@pzh.nl.
Wil je bezwaar maken, dan kan je terecht bij de Juridische afdeling van dienst beheer organisatie. https://www.zuid-holland.nl/contact/
source_data:
The data used will be read real-time from the National Database Road Traffic Data (NDW). Data on waterways is not currently included - Number of vehicles - Type of vehicles - Speed per vehicle HIG Measurement loop data There are measurement loops in provincial roads that record traffic flow in number of vehicles, type of vehicle and speed per vehicle. Only a subset of these loops is accessed real-time to the NDW (National Database on Road Traffic Data) - the rest is used for monitoring and evaluation. As not all measurement loops relevant to the project were available in NDW, a raw dataset was requested from the supplier for the three bridges mentioned in the introduction. This contained the most detailed data of all vehicles travelling over a measurement loop, where each line in the dataset ́is a vehicle. For further use of this data, the individual lines were aggregated by minute with the sum of number of vehicles, average speed and average length and numbers by vehicle classes. Here, between ́e ́e and two years of historical data was used to create the forecast model depending on availability per measurement loop NDW real-time road traffic intensities NDW has up-to-date traffic data of the number of vehicles passing a measurement point per minute. 

Central Object Operation Analysis Log Data (COBALD) bridge opening data COBALD is a system developed for the Province that is linked to the control centre. It contains all historical bridge openings, including the moment (start date/time) and duration of the bridge opening. This historical data was used to prepare and analyse the measurement loop data. Bridge Sense real-time data Additional sensors have been placed on most bridges that detect real-time bridge openings and transmit it to Blue Wave Connecting and the NDW - who make it available as Open Data. This real-time data is used for current bridge status in the developed web application.
methods_and_models: LSTM Long short term memory. Deep learning algorithm Traffic intensity model development Deep learning models are developed in the Keras library (version 2.2.4), an open-source neural network package written in Python. Keras allows researchers to quickly experiment with deep neural networks. Keras had been used in conjunction with TensorFlow (version 1.5.0) as a backend using the GPU variant of the chosen model (section 3) in the experimental phase. A grid-search had been applied parsed from the Scikit-learn machine learning library for Python. All analyses for data cleaning and traffic intensity modelling were performed in Python. Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) are a set of algorithms inspired by the hugely efficient functioning of the human brain to recognise patterns. An ANN consists of artificial neurons and in recent years can be trained to far depth and complexity efficiently by so-called deep learning algorithms. For time-series data such as in this case study, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) are often a suitable solution because here neurons not only factor in information from previous layers of the network, but also include information from previous time points. A powerful variant of RNNs is the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network which was developed specifically to model long time series. In the work presented here, LSTM was chosen as the final algorithm to predict real-time traffic intensities for three bridges First, an LSTM model was trained on historical traffic data where a time series of inputs was used to predict a vector of steps ahead (script 1). In the second case, an encoder-decoder LSTM was used (script 2) where the input time series of data is encoded (encode). The decoder uses this encoded data and makes a prediction one step ahead for each element in the output sequence. The difference is small, as in practice both models predict one sequence ahead. The main difference is that an LSTM model encoder decoder model has information about both the previous step predicted and also the accumulated information from the encoder step is taken into account in predicting the output sequence
human_intervention: The algorithm itself is only decision support. The bridge operator itself makes the final decision. This makes the bridge operator responsible. There is still human interaction in between. The algorithm itself does not decide when the bridge opens and closes.
risks: The Long Short-Term Memory neural networks used can make predictions up to 21 minutes ahead with a correlation coefficient accuracy of 75-95%. This is not 100%. The accuracy of the algorithm could be too low, giving you less insight and reducing your ability to make a decision as a bridge operator. Also, the algorithm could possibly be misinterpreted by the bridge operator. That chance exists, but its impact is very small. Therefore, a pilot is now being done to bring bridge operators into this so that they understand the algorithm properly.
impact: The algorithm does not process any personal data (such as age, gender, income, health, and so on). The information is in no way traceable to a natural person. Moreover, there is always still human intervention and the bridge operator still ultimately determines the best time to open a bridge. The algorithm itself is only decision-supportive.
decision_making_process: Within the process of bridge operation operation. Statutory duty to improve road and waterway traffic and ensure it is safe.
competent_authority: DBI is responsible for the tool and the use and deployment of the algorithm. However, DBI is not responsible for testing the content, that lies with people from engineering.
dpia: No personal data is involved in this algorithm.
dpia_description: No personal data are involved in this algorithm.
objection_procedure: For questions and comments, please contact: digitaalzuidholland@pzh.nl If you wish to raise objections, please contact the Legal Department of service management organisation. https://www.zuid-holland.nl/contact/
description:
South Holland province plays an important role in traffic flow within the region by operating and maintaining more than 100 bridges. Smart ICT solutions offer new opportunities to finely link up-to-date traffic information to real-time shipping information via sensors and algorithms. 
Of these 100 bridges, 55 have sensors that monitor whether the bridge is open or closed. For an ever-increasing number of these bridges, the province faces a challenge to optimally match traffic flow with shipping and increasing traffic density. The province is committed to smarter, safer and more efficient passage to meet these challenges. 
In this, the 'Impact Monitor Bridge Openings' project has taken a substantial step in predicting traffic intensities around a number of important bridges in the province of South Holland. The Long Short-Term Memory neural networks used can make predictions up to 21 minutes ahead with a correlation coefficient accuracy of 75-95%. The developed algorithms were deployed within an Azure cloud environment. It has been delivered as a user-friendly web application in which live shipping and traffic information is presented. This information is used by the application to recommend the optimal time for a bridge opening to a bridge operator. 
In a next phase, this information can be fed directly back to the traffic network which, for example, allows navigation software to take into account planned bridge openings. In summary, the developed web application uses recent artificial intelligence technology that allows bridge operators to combine expert knowledge with the latest technology.
mprd: It does not contain any personal data.
monitoring: During the pilot phase, a dashboard was developed that shows how the algorithm is deployed and where it is deployed.
performance_standard: Performance is of huge importance - considering bridge operators do not want to wait for the outcome of the model. The Non Functional Requirement (NFR) is that the forecast should be seen on the screen within 3 seconds. The final solution offers a response time between 0.5 and 2 seconds.

name: Informing end of detention or leave
description_short: One of the tasks of the Justice Information Portal (Injus) is to inform municipalities when a detainee's detention begins/ends or when the detainee goes on leave. This can be done in the context of reintegration or in certain categories of cases covered by the Administrative Information Facility for Detainees (BIJ). In addition, Injus is also responsible for sending a notification to the Public Prosecutor's Office (OM) if a victim needs to be informed about the start or end of a detention or leave. For more information, visit https://www.justid.nl/algoritmeregister/informeren-detentie

name: Register criminal database
description_short: In the criminal justice chain, various organisations work on the investigation, prosecution and trial of offenders and the proper execution of sentences. The criminal justice database (SKDB) is the system that supports the criminal justice chain in determining the leading identity in criminal cases. In the SKDB, the name and other personal data (the personalia) of a suspect or convicted person are stored under that person's unique criminal justice chain number (SKN). The SKN is the means of communicating within the criminal justice chain about whom it concerns. When a person is registered with the SKDB with a set of personal details by, for example, the police, an algorithm in the SKDB is used in determining whether the person already has a SKN. If so, new data can be placed under the existing SKN. If the person does not already have an SKN, a new SKN will be created and the data will be placed under it. For more information, please visit https://www.justid.nl/algoritmeregister/inschrijven-strafrechtketendatabank

name: intelligent traffic control installation (iVRI)
description_short: Safe, autonomous and automatic control of traffic flows at an intersection through an iVRI.
type: Within the algorithm, all types are used to achieve a continuous outcome, so measuring, diagnosing, predicting and advancing insight is incorporated.
goal: 1. Ensuring efficient traffic flow at intersections with iVRIs in a safe (without accidents) and credible (without people waiting for nothing / logical order) way. 2. Generation of data for checking correct operation by Province, and as input for the central national data point UDAP. 3. The deployment of iVRIs also contributes to improved accessibility, increased travel comfort, road safety and greening of mobility.
proportionality: Traffic intensity in and around cities is increasing, the policy goals served by road managers are multiple: traffic flow, accessibility, road safety, liveability, sustainability, economic vitality should all be promoted as much as possible. This should also take into account the different behaviour of traffic participants (walking, cycling, passenger cars, public transport, trucks, emergency and auxiliary services), each with their own characteristics, needs and limitations, where political-administrative priorities regularly require different accents in accommodating one group over another (e.g. more priority for cyclists over passenger cars) and the area also continues to develop and change (think of new residential areas and business premises and/or office locations). Within this playing field of goals, interests and changes, iVRIs are necessary to implement this efficiently in practice.
lawful_basis: The basis for deploying iVRIs is a combination of the province's various tasks (in particular: safety, mobility, spatial planning, and financial tasks).
source_data: The data used by the algorithm is the real-time data measured by the control system itself using, among other things, detection loops and push buttons, as well as data retrieved via nationwide UDAP. These specific data flows (origins from mobiles and on-board computers) have been labelled as (potentially) person traceable data. All parties processing this data have to sign a data processor agreement.
methods_and_models: https://www.talking-traffic.com/nl/ www.crow.nl
human_intervention: The formal road authority may intervene in the operation of the iVRI including the algorithm. For each intersection, a unique algorithm is developed by suppliers based on the layout of the intersection and the province's policy. Each intersection consists of hundreds of parameters that can be adjusted by traffic engineers to improve the flow of the intersections based on policies (road safety, flow, liveability,,,,).
risks: The risks are frequent but also small. As soon as traffic unsafe situations could arise (conflicting directions get green), the algorithm will abort and the traffic lights will start flashing. This is because in addition to the 'control algorithm' that regulates the traffic lights, there is also a control algorithm. The abort is done by this separate safety-control algorithm. Apart from this, general traffic law also applies when the traffic lights are 'flashing'. Traffic safety is a basic design principle in traffic lights and the algorithms used.
impact: The algorithm determines the position/colour of the traffic lights and thus whether a citizen is allowed to proceed or must stop.
decision_making_process: The deployment of iVRIs is necessary to efficiently carry out the task as road manager of provincial roads.
documentation:
Het algoritme is een cluster van verschillende algoritme's van verschillende leveranciers die allemaal verschillende nuaces hebben. Voor elk kruispunt wordt een uniek algoritme ontwikkeld door verschillende leveranciers:
www.vialis.nl
www.dynniq.nl
www.swarco.nl
competent_authority: The formal road authority, being Province of North Brabant.
objection_procedure: A citizen can report a malfunctioning/non-functioning control system through an electric form. https://fd9.formdesk.com/provincienoordbrabant/Infra_melding_provinciale_wegen/?get=1&sidn=c34ae56da0cf4088b5bbd9fc1b320828
description: The algorithm detects the presence of different mobilities (cars / bikes / trucks / pedestrians) using detection loops, push buttons, mobile app data, and on-board computer. This is likely to become an even wider palette of inputs in the future. Based on this data and predefined criteria, the most efficient flow is calculated per cycle (+/- 90 or 120 seconds) in a safe and credible way. On this, in Real-Time, the control algorithm adjusts the traffic lights (who gets green first, etc.). The 'control algorithm' is checked by the 'control algorithm' to guarantee the safety of the intersections.
application_url: Voor elk kruispunt met iVRI's wordt een specifiek algoritme gemaakt door verschillende leveranciers. Deze informatie is nu (nog) niet beschikbaar.
monitoring: https://www.talking-traffic.com/nl/ www.crow.nl
performance_standard:
Monthly functional maintenance is performed on the worst-performing system in North Brabant. 
On average, every traffic light is physically checked once every 5 years to see if the system is still working as it should. Once a year there is preventive technical maintenance.

name: Remote Sensing area classification based on AI image recognition
description_short: Based on image recognition of satellite imagery and analysis, changes in natura2000 areas are visualised and mapped in detail. We do this for ecological purposes (nitrogen policy).
category: Nature, vegetation change partly due to nitrogen and exhaust gases CO2
status: Two nature reserves are in use (pilot). The algorithm exists but is not yet in use by ecologists.
goal: The biodiversity of the living environment is lower than desired. Government agencies have the task of improving it. Based on image recognition, changes in natura2000 areas are visualised and mapped in detail. We do this for habitat quality. In this way, plant and animal species can be recognised, such as insects. In this way, we can map the distribution of exotic and indicator species. We can also take recovery measures against nitrogen on this basis. Within nature reserves, you have certain nature that is sensitive to nitrogen. If too much nitrogen comes down on them they deteriorate. An example is recognising grassing. If nitrogen is deposited there, plants such as nettle grasses can grow. This is what you want to prevent in dunes.
proportionality: Open and clear communication (transparency) about the deployment of the use of satellite imagery is important for residents' acceptance and people's trust in (the deployment of) the technology. It is purely for nature and nitrogen policy.
contact_email:
Voor vragen en opmerkingen kan je terecht bij: digitaalzuidholland@pzh.nl.
Wil je bezwaar maken, dan kan je terecht bij de Juridische afdeling van dienst beheer organisatie. https://www.zuid-holland.nl/contact/
source_data: This dataset contains snapshots of automatically generated vegetation structure classifications of Natura 2000 sites, based on SuperView Netherlands Space Office (NSO) satellite imagery. The images are made available every one to four months by the NSO and segmented into vegetation structure classes through modelling. The analysed images go back to 2019. The data is visualised in an ArcGIS Operations Dashboard where all segmented snapshots can be compared.  The dataset also includes Lidar from Actueel Hoogtebestand Nederland (AHN)
methods_and_models: Scikit learn: package models open source within Python. Random forest for recognising vegetation structures. https://scikit-learn.org/stable/
human_intervention: Yes by ecologists.
risks: The model is 85-90% watertight. Human intervention (ecologist) is needed, to check things.  It is also good to look at drone footage additionally.
department: Afdeling Informatisering en Automatisering & Water en Groen
impact:
The resolution of the images is 50 centimetres of raw data from NSO, with aggregations. The ecologist gets to see 3-4 metres. There is no impact on humans, as they cannot be recognised on the satellite images (subject to privacy check NSO). 

Elevation data of the Netherlands. Actueel Hoogtebestand Nederland (AHN) radar system by the Dutch government with Lidar (https://www.ahn.nl/).
decision_making_process: Decision-making process nitrogen policy (change in vegetation Natura2000) and use by ecologists within the province.
competent_authority: Department of Water and Green
dpia: No, because there is no personal data involved.
objection_procedure: For questions and comments, please contact: digitaalzuidholland@pzh.nl If you wish to raise objections, please contact the Legal Department of service management organisation. https://www.zuid-holland.nl/contact/
description:
The algorithm classifies vegetation structure of Natura 2000 areas, based on modelled satellite image recognition. Province of South Holland is measured by various sensors (image, LIDAR, IR, multispectral, microwave, etc). This is done from satellites, aircraft and helicopters. Much of the data is available for free. Exploiting such area-wide measurement series can give a big boost to monitoring natural areas. 
Interpreting remote sensing data into ecologically relevant insights can be an important building block of a digital twin nature. These measurement series can provide the 'skeleton' or framework on which the digital twin can be further built.  Drone imagery, combined with species recognition, provides a tool to obtain very high-resolution data.   
It increases coverage and provides greater updating for the province.
monitoring: Not yet in use, so not yet monitored.
performance_standard:
The intended result is to roll out a simple structural model (sand, grass, forest) to other N2000 areas (in addition to dune areas 3A) across entire province. 
Accuracy is 85% of image recognition with F1 score.

name: Selection aid WBU table
description_short:
Traffic managers want to be able to schedule predictable road maintenance based on workable hours. To carry out maintenance, traffic measures (in the form of partial road closures) have to be taken. This can adversely affect the road's capacity to handle traffic. 
Workable hours are determined by: -the capacity of the site; -the time of day (day, hour); -the minimum required residual capacity of the site; -the effect of the type of traffic measure on capacity. 

Workable hours are now determined statically. The aim of this phase is to determine whether we can determine these workable hours data-driven. 
The definition of data-driven in this phase is: maximum capacity of the location is determined by actually measured intensities (from NDW traffic data, with interpolation) at the same times. 
Using historical data, you can use this algorithm to see what type of closure and traffic measure can be applied to a road.  You can also see which times are suitable. The WBU table selection tool is partly used to draw up the WBU table. When drawing up the tool, certain agreements from the business community and other policy choices by PZH are also taken into account in addition to the tool.
website:
De (tijdelijke) URL is: https://c6ae6fa2db7da44c79581d7e.azurewebsites.net/ 
Er komt nog een URL waarmee eerst via PZH netwerk moet worden ingelogd. Tevens is het (nog) niet de bedoeling dat deze URL door externe wordt gebruikt. In eerste instantie wordt de WBU doorvertaald in een tabel (zoas nu ook het geval is).
status: Currently, the last teething problems are being removed from the tool (Nov, 2022)
goal:
Reduce operational costs and increase traffic safety -Increase traffic safety The CROW96b provides calculation methods to determine at which traffic intensity at which traffic measure may be applied. The current WBU table does not take this into account. Because a web application displays the WBU per type of traffic measure, the requirements from the guideline are always met. This keeps traffic safety guaranteed.  

-Operational costs Unlike the old WBU table, the web application makes it possible to calculate the WBU per day. Experience shows that the traffic pattern on a Wednesday and Friday is significantly quieter than on a Tuesday or Thursday. The case study below shows the financial implications of this. Our DBO contractor has scheduled mowing works throughout December in the Hoeksche-Waard. The work will be carried out in accordance with a half lane closure (Fig 1323b). The old WBU table indicates that the WBU is between 09:00 and 15:00. The web application to be created indicates that on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, work can be done from 09:00 to 16:00. This implies that the contractor can work an extra 3 hours per week. This is therefore 12 hours extra per month. By having an extra 12 hours of working time, the contractor will not have to hit the road as often. Assuming that the work is carried out through a pre-warning truck, action truck and end truck, this saves the rental and operational costs of three work vehicles and three drivers. This can save money. This is just an example of one contractor at work. Around 2,400 TVM applications are submitted every year. By applying the WBU application, a large proportion of these applications can probably be processed more efficiently and save costs.  
It is plausible, that thanks to the WBU web application, traffic congestion is reduced. This will also save social costs in the form of fewer vehicle loss hours.
proportionality: Safety is increased as the CROW96B guideline is met, with less congestion and fewer vehicle loss hours.
lawful_basis: The algorithm gives an advice/prediction.  But it takes into account the applicable guidelines of CROW 96B and APV (general local bye-laws) laid down. And the conditions of Melvin(Reporting disruptions of Infrastructure in the Netherlands).
contact_email:
Voor vragen en opmerkingen kan je terecht bij: digitaalzuidholland@pzh.nl.
Wil je bezwaar maken, dan kan je terecht bij de Juridische afdeling van dienst beheer organisatie. https://www.zuid-holland.nl/contact/
source_data: -Loop data (how fast traffic drives, how long a vehicle is, to distinguish between truck and passenger cars; intensities) -Information routes with how many lanes and maximum speed -Planning data in Melvin -SWUNG 2 model -Floating car data
methods_and_models:
Functioning of the model now: We indicate: -Which N-road it concerns -We indicate the start and end point in hectometry -the type of traffic measure (alternate lane with right of way) -the date in next Monday We get back:
-An overview of the time slots (per half hour), including a red/green score per time slot on workable hours for the whole week -The historical profile determines the score of the time slots -The historical profile per time slot is calculated based on the same time and weekday, of the past weeks (growing history since June 2021)
human_intervention: We are currently testing out the application. We are checking whether it matches our own and road inspectors' findings. In this way, we are trying to filter out any bugs from the tool.
risks:
The following risks have been identified. 

-Data from traffic loops does not cover the entire road network of the province > state of play Nov 2021: NO RISK. 

Initially, it was uncertain whether sufficient data would be available to predict traffic volumes on all provincial roads. However, based on NDW data and data from the SWUNG2 model, traffic intensities can be predicted per 100-metre road section. The methods behind this, are based on the methods from the noise and air calculation model and thus already proven.  

-Calculation rules from CROW cannot be applied > state of play Nov 2021: NO RISK Within the province of South Holland, five different deposits are used for daily management and maintenance. Using the methods from CROW96b, it is relatively easy to determine, based on traffic intensities, when which barrier can be applied. Point of attention is that we still need to properly mirror these methods with the current WBU. 

-Problems during further software development > state of play Nov 2021: SMALL RISK Risks are tracked and monitored in progress reports.
impact: With the algorithm, there is less disruption for road users. In addition, road safety is increased.
decision_making_process: The algorithm gives an advice/prediction.  But it takes into account the applicable guidelines of CROW 96B and APV (general local bye-laws) laid down. And the conditions of Melvin(Reporting disruptions of Infrastructure in the Netherlands).
documentation:
Richtlijn TVM (inclusief huidige WBU-tabel)  
https://www.zuid-holland.nl/onderwerpen/verkeer-vervoer/tijdelijke/melvin/  

Onderzoek WBU Frank de Winter 2018 (LET OP: rapport is niet openbaar) 
http://idms/otcs/llisapi.dll/link/656243217

dpia_description: No personal details, also nothing known about the vehicles or license plates.
objection_procedure: For questions and comments, please contact: digitaalzuidholland@pzh.nl If you wish to raise objections, please contact the Legal Department of service management organisation. https://www.zuid-holland.nl/contact/
revision_date: Jaarlijks onderhoud beheer gaat via afdeling I&A
description:
A workable hours table (WBU table) is used in the province of South Holland.  This WBU table indicates within which time windows which traffic restriction measures may be taken by contractors, for the purpose of carrying out maintenance on Provincial roads. This table is based on knowledge and experience of supervisors and traffic managers. It is not numerically based. The WBU table is now not based on actual traffic situations. The result may be unnecessarily strict control (e.g. working only at night), while on some roads work can be done during a wider period. This can save on operational costs. 
The starting point should be: measuring is knowing. We measure on the basis of the actual busy streets and the expected nuisance caused. Figuring the table helps us, to have the conversation with stakeholders. 
In addition, the WBU now does not distinguish between the different types of traffic measures that can be applied. This means that there may be traffic measures on the road where, according to the traffic density and the guidelines from the CROW, this is actually not allowed. This can lead to traffic unsafe situations. A professionalisation effort is needed to ensure that the WBU table is substantiated numerically. By numerically substantiating our WBU, we can transparently indicate to stakeholders why traffic-restricting measures are allowed at certain times. This allows us to work on efficiency and increase traffic safety.
mprd: Based on NDW data, public data and based on the SWUNG 2 model.
monitoring: The web application is tested against its own findings and counts.
performance_standard: Results: - An overview of the time periods (per half hour), including a red/green score per time period on workable hours for the whole week - The historical profile determines the score of the time periods - The historical profile per time period is calculated on the basis of the same time and weekday, of the past weeks (growing history since June 2021)

name: Gladness reporting system
description_short: The algorithm uses sensor data to make a calculation for predictions of slipperiness risks. These predictions are used to determine where to grit (preventively), in consultation with meteorologists. In addition, the algorithm can issue various alarms, for example when there is a chance of wet road sections freezing or slipperiness due to condensation.
goal: The aim of the algorithm is to ensure road safety and traffic flow, by reporting slipperiness risks in time, allowing gritting to be carried out in time.
proportionality: Negative impacts and risks are negligible. The expected benefits mainly focus on more efficient process and discard policies.
source_data: The data used is the sensor data from the measurement points: - Road temperature - Air temperature - Subsoil temperature - Precipitation - Conductivity - Dew point temperature No sensitive/personal data is used.
human_intervention: The algorithm is advisory, and has no decision-making power. There is always a human who decides whether gritting will indeed be done or not.
risks: If the algorithm does not work properly and gritting is not carried out in time, road safety may be compromised, in addition to which throughput may be reduced. This risk is overcome because gritting is always done in consultation with meteorologists. If meteorologists indicate that they think it should be gritted, while the algorithm does not indicate this, a decision can still be made to grit. A second risk is that the situation is examined at specific measuring points (15 in Brabant) at which the risk to the surrounding area is determined. This can lead to inaccuracies. This risk is also overcome by cooperating with meteorologists.
impact: Citizens, especially road users, using the road network. They notice whether it has been gritted or not.
decision_making_process: The smoothness reporting system improves road safety and traffic flow, thereby contributing to the mobility task. The mobility task is a statutory duty. For the safety of the road network, the Province has an obligation of effort, which obliges it to make an effort to keep the road network safe, which includes gritting. There is no obligation of result. Section 16 onwards of the Roads Act.
competent_authority: The Province owns the algorithm, but it cannot make adjustments itself. Maintenance and adjustments are done by Rijkswaterstaat The calculation rules used are from the KMNI.
monitoring: Since the maintenance is under the Department of Public Works, they check the operation of the algorithm, they calibrate the system annually. In addition, the province automatically receives notification in case of a broken sensor.

name: Fight against fraud
description_short: Combating fraud by residents in services for Work and Income products. More specific information regarding this algorithm will follow.
human_intervention: The algorithm does not make an independent decision. When a printout is made of these data, a manual check is made to see whether there is indeed an irregularity. Next, data from the address in question is enriched with data from other organisations (provided this is the case) and, finally, it is jointly considered at the case table whether the address will be checked.
decision_making_process: The algorithm filters for irregularities in the logical consistency of objective data. It thus provides a preliminary (information) on which addresses might be subject to fraud. This data is compiled from data from WenI, the intelligence agency and public services.
